38542598.review:
tl;dr: A true survival roguelike RPG set in a very deep and detailed world.

This really IS a [b]true survival[/b] game. 
You cannot just go somewhere and attack a wolf with your sword to gain 50 xp.

First of all, you more than likely won't have a sword - they are hard to come by and you will have to gather many boards, furs, leathers and food to finally get enough value together to trade in for a sword.

Also, good luck finding a wolf. In all my hours so far (of which I spent quite a few hunting), I did not encounter a single one. You do hear them, though. And hope they stay far away...

Oh, and if you do find one, it will very likely be deadly. Combat in general is deadly in this game. Even small game like a wolverine might already cause a wound that can kill you if unprepared. And even if you start out with good combat stats, you will be lacking in other stats and have a hard time surviving.

Of course, you will not have to worry about a single wolf. As is realistic, they hunt in packs. A single bear is more deadly than a wolf, of course, but I don't see how anyone but a perfectly equipped seasoned warrior would be able to bring a pack of wolves down.

And finally... you won't get 50xp as this game has no XP or even a level system. You have skills and they improve by using them. And since combat is very deadly... well, let's just say it would be a good idea to train a very long time before setting out for trouble.

[b]What CAN you do then?[/b]
As of writing this review, I spent about 25 hours building a hut next to a lake to survive the winter. 
By falling trees, cutting them into logs and boards, building all those walls and floors and of course the fireplace. 
All of that while having to catch fish to eat, hunting and trapping game in the wilderness to skin and tan the hides (a multi-step days spanning process), taking care of my wounds because a crazed wolverine attacked me and almost killed my poor reindeer companion and continuously trading whatever I could to afford better tools, weapons and dried food for the winter months - because I do not yet have a smoking cabin, nor is it winter to dry my fishes.

And the best part: Every single step listed here is governed by skills that you create your character with and that will slowly improve over time. So not only a true survival game but also a true RPG.

Oh, and all those things I mentioned do not even cover half of all the mechanics of this game.

38502297.review:
Its been almost a year since my adventure began. Since I struck out from my home village where I had lived my entire to experience the greater world. For months I desperately scraped together a meagre existence, fishing, hunting rabbits, trapping foxes and when desperate enough, stealing from villages under the cover of darkness. My mind casts over all of my numerous near death experiences. Ive been tracked by a pack of wolves, fallen off a cliff, butted by a bull elk and wrestled by a fully grown bear.

 My most dangerous foe however, a lone poorly armed Njerpez raider, half starved and half frozen. It was a savage affair, arrows were notched at range, spear struck sword in close combat and countless blows were exchanged. Strike after strike after strike. Our weapons had been lost in the struggle, we drew knives. Blade bites flesh. We were exhausted, both bleeding from a dozen wounds. Our knives were lost too. We wrestled like two worn out boxers. He collapsed and I fell on him like a spider. I lifted a heavy stone and brought it down on his face, over and over. He finally lets out one last rattling breath. I collapsed in the snow beside him and woke hours later unable to walk. It took me two days to drag myself back to camp eating roots, weeds and a frozen bird carcass to survive. I saw things in the woods at night.

But that was then and this is now, its different you know.

Im standing tall at the edge of a river, a Njerpez camp lying empty in my wake. Im wearing skis, thick furs, a battered iron helmet and gauntlets aswell as thick mail shirt. I feel like a giant, no man can fell me, my long axe has drank the blood of many Njerpez today. I begin to stride across the thick ice of the frozen river.

I am a different man than the one that set out all those seasons ago, in the thaw I shall use the waterways to travel far and wide to seek out other figthers to test my mettle agaisnt, yes, I will be a warrior of the greatest renown in all of the Unrea- *Crack*

Is the ice as thick as I thought it was?

*Splash*

Swimming in freezing water is hard, swimming in freezing water wearing fifty pounds of iron armour and over laden with battle trophies is impossible. Exhaustion and coldwater shock set in quickly. What a way to go. Perhaps the spirit of the waters have something agaisnt hubris?

Unreal world is one of my favourite games of all time. Ignore the hour count on my steam profile I have a couple of hundred hours in the freeware version of this game. (I highly reccomend you play it if your on the fence, its exactly the same as the steam version just free). I ended up buying it on steam because I wanted to support the incredible developers of this game who have been working on it for 25 years. People might get turned off by its complexity but I can tell you, Unreal World has of the BEST tutorials I've ever seen in a game of its kind. Its immersive, unique setting of Iron age Finland is so well realised and steeped in mysticism and history you'll lose yourself in it. 

What the heck are you waiting for, go get mauled to death in the woods. You'll have a blast.

This game is true brilliance, it might look like a simple- plain game, but the AI of the animals is just.... Incredibly good. I'll describe it to you quickly, since this is one of the many things that really made me mindblown.

I started out with a Kaumo (There are cultures in the game), basically maxed out his fishing/spear skills and dropped myself near a lake on the east side of the map. I luckily spawned next to a fjord, a fishermans heaven. I started fishing and soon i was stocked for the upcoming 5 days. Used those days to explore for villages. When i came across the cabin of an old kaumo man, I sneaked behind the man and planted my spear in his rear-skull, stole his kota material (kota is a fur-tent) and his food. Then i wen't off to live near the fjord. After i put up my kota it was time to hunt some elk. I looked near my campsite for some elk, and found one. Mostly one elk means there COULD be a herd nearby so i wasted 3-4 days building a trap fence of 3 hexes. During this peroid, i was strongly convinced by the amount of traps that there was atleast a herd of 3+ elk nearby my trap fence. So, i waited for 2 days and my trap pit was filled. With only one elk. This elk made so much tracks that i really thought that there'd be a herd of 3+ elk. I was really annoyed, and just slitted the elks throat with my edge of my spear and let him bleed out to retrieve him the next day.

Now for the finale, when i made my kota, i attracted the attention of a wonderful lynx. These critters are 9/10 times more afraid of you then you of them. Luckily this was the case. But this small lynx was too quick to catch so i instead i placed a trap pit and threw in some bait hoping he'd take it.

He did not, take the bait.

I think he was maddened by the fact i underestimated him, so his time to take revenge was begun.

This fierce predator encircled my kota looking for a entrance to bite me to death while i was asleep. I woke up in the early morning with a thigh wound, then a gruesome hand wound, and then i found out the critter was finishing me off in my sleep! Quickly i grabbed my spear and tried to stab the c*nt but he quickly ran out my kota before i could do him any harm. After that, i feared for my life and crawled to the wooden cabin from the old kaumo man i murdered before. I literally slept next to the rotting carcass of this old man for 13 days straight. 

After that it was time to also slit the throat of this forest critter, i wen't back to my kota in the fjord (Still wounded) and camped the entrance of my kota. I knew that our little house cat saw me enter my kota. And then, two hours later he steps in the kota, sees me camping, and sisses at me and tries to leg it. I manage to hit him in the skull but it isn't enough and he books it into the woods. Fun fact the cat is still visiting me every day. And he just won't get trapped by all the trap pits i have laying around. He just memorises all the traps i have build and reminds himself not to go near that area.

The AI is wonderful in this game. This game deserves a 95/100

I would only wish that keeping a good balance with the forest spirits was crucial, because it actually makes you fear the spirits. In earlier builds the forest spirits could actually call mythical creatures to kill you. In the later builds, this isn't the case unatfortunately.

I have played UnReal World over many years and many versions. I believe it has been installed on every PC I have owned :) I spent countless hours surviving, dying, exploring, trying new things and being amazed at just how deep this game is. I was even inspired to write stories of my adventures. I have taken lengthy breaks but the tug to return and dive back in always returns, and back I go. This time around I found the game is now on Steam, so bought yet another version. 

If you need flashy graphics and hand-holding to enjoy a game then URW will not be for you. This game is not flashy nor easy. It tosses you in the deep end with only a few tools (and lots of key strokes to remember!). You will die ugly deaths, learn from them, and do a little better the next time. Nothing is overly simple. The skill system has great depth and a level of realism that is impressive. I could go on and on, but will just say if old school, roguelike survival is your thing, then do NOT miss out on URW :)

37841062.review:
UnReal World is an old-school, RPG turn-based survival game. It's not overly hard, but the complexity and learning process will likely lead to a few untimely deaths.

Every single movement causes a slight passage in time. Take a step forward, time passes. Turn left or right, time passes. Activities, such as pulling brush off a tree, skinning an animal, filling a cup with water, or crafting some gloves brings up a progress bar while time passes automatically (with the option to stop mid-activity.) Doing something time consuming, such as building a wall for your shelter, generally takes some planning as you have to pay attention to your hunger/thirst/temperature/energy while doing so. Seems pretty standard, but when you're tracking some big game and the tracks converge on a heavily traffic area, turning left or right to look around means that animal gets further away.

The controls are somewhat confusing as there are key bindings for every activity. There's in-game help, but it might be more helpful to find a wiki that will list all actions in an easy to access format. Of course, as with all games, you should hopefully get used to it eventually.

The game is available for free outside of Steam, so if you're on the fence, I highly recommend grabbing it and giving it a shot. However, if you like it, PLEASE buy it because something like this deserves support. This game has been in development for 20~ years and they keep going.

36748535.review:
Unreal World es un juego que podriamos denominar rogue-like de supervivencia. 

A pesar de sus toscos gráficos (teniendo en cuenta que es un juego que se está desarrollando desde 1992), estamos ante un juego cuya profundidad y realismo en la supervivencia es asombroso.

Nos situamos en la Edad de Hierro en una Finlandia no real (Unreal), donde nuestro personaje a la tierna edad de 16 años debe iniciar una nueva vida en plena naturaleza. El personaje deberá ser creado eligiendo su sexo, a qué tribu pertenece, y podemos subir algunas de sus habilidades. Teniendo en cuenta que dicho personaje cuenta con diversos atributos, un buen surtido de habilidades y unas cualidades en diversas armas y combate en general, y que estas varían en la creación del personaje, varian durante la elección de tribu, y varían al aumentar algunas,    hacen que cada personaje que creemos sea totalmente diferente a los anteriores y sea disestro para algunas tareas y torpe en muchas otras. Es humano, un humano corriente, y tiene muchas debilidades, cualquier cosa ahí fuera puede matarle. Además elegiremos una pequeña historia de comienzo, la cual cambiará nuestro punto de partida y los objetos con los que comenzamos.

El juego en sí podriamos decir que se realiza en turnos, ya que si no realizas ninguna acción y no te mueves, el juego permanece inmovil. Cada acción permitirá moverse a tu entorno y requerirá de tiempo, que puede variar entre pocos minutos (rezar o hacer fuego) a varias horas (talar o pescar por ejemplo). Conforme realizas acciones y/o viajas, pasarán las horas, amanecerá, anochecerá, ...y tu personaje se cansará y deberá dormir. Pasarán los dias, y con suerte las estaciones si consigues sobrevivir lo suficiente. La muerte aquí es permanente.

Caza con trampas o sigue el rastro de animales, pesca, tala y consigue madera para tu refugio, tus herramientas o armas, para hacer fuego..., descubre aldeas perdidas en mitad de la nada y entabla relación con los habitantes, o si estás suficientemente armado y preparado arrasa con todo y roba sus pertenencias, viaja y descubre, ...es un juego totalmente abierto donde lo único importante es que permanezcas con vida.   

¿Recuerdas que mencioné que el juego empezó a crearse en 1992? Pues dicho esto olvidate del ratón, aquí se utiliza el teclado y la cantidad de ordenes que podemos dar a nuestro personaje hace que utilicemos practicamente cada una de las teclas del teclado (¡Y más ya que algunas acciones requerirán que pulsemos MAYUSCULAS más una letra de acción). Por suerte el juego incluye una guia y ayuda con el teclado, pero la cantidad de acciones puede abrumar.  

¿Recomendable?

100% Sí:
- No te molestan los gráficos.
- No te importa  tener que usar/aprender infinidad de teclas
- Te gustan los juegos rogue-like y la supervivencia.

Un juego muy profundo e interesante cuya dificultad elevada lo hace muy adictivo.

36680144.review:
This is a hard-core Rogue-Like RPG game based on early iron age Finland. You play as a sole character trying to survive day by day by keeping one-self warm, well fed and not being thirsty. If you have nothing to eat then you'll start to starve - and dy by day get weaker until you get food or die from hunger many days later.

When you play the game - then when ever you die - the game automatically deletes your save game - forcing you to start from a new.

X ways to die (list):
Die from hunger
Die from dehidralization
Die from freezing to death
Die from being too much overheated
Die from sinking
Die from being killed from a single "lucky" arrow in your head from the bow
Die from bleeding
Die from untreated illness (bad wound)
Die from failing to hunt a bear
Die from attacking the Njarpezzit warrior village alone
And many other ways to die.

Bought this game years ago outside of Steam, was happy to buy it again. Possibly one of the best classic non-hack roguelikes, up there with ZAngband and ADOM.

Controls take a lot of getting used to, especially given the vast array of context-sensitive commands available.

Definitely not for those who don't want to read, as most everything you do results in a full page of text, and there's a huge set of reference and historical material available in the game.

If you're looking for something similar to Dwarf Fortress but with less management-sim and more hands-on action, this is absolutely what you want.

34070199.review:
Wasted many hours of my youth with this game long before it ever showed up on Steam.  I've purchased this game 3 times now in one form or another and I don't regret the purchases one bit, the developer more than deserves the money for the time he's poured into this game.

What a lot of roguelikes miss out on is having a balance of complexity, challenge and fun.  There are too many survival roguelikes that are an ocean wide but a puddle's depth, this is not one of them.  This game throws you right into the unforgiving wilderness and you're meant to survive right from the word "go".  Surviving isn't an easy task, food will be hard to come by, but when you actually successfully hunt wildlife you really feel accomplished because it's not black and white simple, more times than not you're going to have your target outrun or outsmart you, or even at times outfight you.  

All of your survival skills are stat-based, everything from building shelters, crafting traps, animal tracking, fishing, etc.  and the more you use them the more proficient you become in those skills.  Also beware of hostile creatures or Njerpez warriors roaming the wilderness that will make short work of you early-game.

There is lots of depth here with this game, almost complex at times, especially with the confusing sub-menus within the skills and far-from-optimal UI.  But with enough time you'll soon memorize what all they hotkeys are for each skill.

The game is absolutely unforgiving.  Your first few attempts at it expect hunger to be your biggest enemy, in which you'll need to figure out the best way you'd like to gather food.  Personally I like fishing while laying some snare traps around just outside of camp to try and keep me well fed, but a high foraging skill and enough luck (and proper season) will keep you going as well.

All in all, a fantastic game if you like wilderness survival games that don't stray far from the realm of reality.  It feels quite authentic and I enjoy that.

34045423.review:
If the hour counter was measuring my gameplay since 2008 I would have been slightly embarrassed by what would be easily over 2000 hours of skirmishes with Njerpez, berry gathering, fire starting and log hauling.

This game may as well be one of the 6 Soul Gems of the independent development/publishing scene of the last decade, spanning almost all my own brief lifetime in active development.
In gameplay hours itself, I bet only Dwarf Fortress and KSP would overthrow my time spent with URW.

This is the survival game that should have defined the survival genre.
THE ROGUELIKE THAT ALL ROGUELIKES SHOULD ABIDE TO AND PAY HEED.

Instead, today, it is a relic from a not-so-distant past; of less flair and effects but more imaginative gameplay and conscious writing than current standards.
But dismissing URW by it's crude looks, unpolished interface or any of the indicators that this game began development circa 1992 would be a mistake you shouldn't make.

I do recommend you to buy this game, despite it being available for free since 201X in the developer site.
I do recommend you to donate to the developer even after purchasing this game on Steam.
I do recommend you to play UnReal World for several hours.

33791731.review:
[u][b] [h1] Worth purchasing at full price. [/h1] [/b][/u]
[b]Note that you can get the game for free at http://www.unrealworld.fi/[/b] 


[h1]Experience[/h1]
I've played this gem of a game for nearly 9 years and I can't even estimate the amount of hours I've devoted to it. I purchased several version licenses during this period prior to it being made available for free and now it's finally obtainable on Steam. I primarily purchased it here to support Sami and Erkka while also giving it a review. The game is still being updated regularly and it appears it'll continue doing so for the unforeseeable future. The developers have refined this piece with commitment and dedication for 25 years which is downright amazing.

[h1]UnReal World[/h1]
It's a very slow paced game where one's choices has ramifications and over time you'll begin to feel an obligation to contemplate every decision you've made and intend to make as it could end up being the last for your character. The unfathomable depth of detail in this game makes it incredible for immersion. The fear of death greatly enhances this and the longer you survive, the greater the anxiety and dismay. Your character actions are based on realism, so consider wisely whether you should fight or flee when stumbling upon a pack of wolves or if you should risk your characters life hunting a bear for that well needed fat and calories for winter. I've always thought it's worth to progress in a sensible manner. Although as such, UnReal World does require a lot of your time. There's also quite a steep learning curve for the controls, but once you've adapted, you'll have it in your muscle memory and it'll become intuitive. The satisfaction you'll feel after setting yourself up to a task and finally completing it weeks later is monumental. While also making it heart breaking when you fail. This is a very difficult game for beginners and death is almost guaranteed. Even the most experienced players will have challenging moments that may end up with their characters dying. However, don't be deterred by the game having permanent player-character deaths. It adds so much to the game and the replay value is immense. [b]UnReal World sends you into genuine wilderness survival.[/b]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I've loved and hated this game ever since I got it. I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys the earlier generation of games. As well as those who are considering giving them a try. 

[h1]Feedback[/h1]
Posting your own experiences with UnReal World whether good or bad assists potential newcomers in making their decision in whether to purchase the game or not.

33600480.review:
Unintuitive, challenging, old-school, and absolutely unforgiving. You need a good imagination and some patience to enjoy this game, and a bit of experience with older, clunkier games will help. I have to disagree with other users - I haven't found the game experience to be "unfair". Yes, sometimes an enemy will get a lucky shot and get you in the head with an arrow, and you'll die. Yes, it is hard to kill bears. Yes, you can work all winter to build a nice cabin, only to absent-mindedly fall through the thinning ice carrying too much gear and drown. In all of these cases, I felt that the challenge was fair, and I could recognize the mistakes I made that led to the death. I felt each death was meaningful and I learned a lot about the game each time, and I am still learning. 

Once I got over the initial learning curve, this has easily been one of the best and most immersive experiences I've had with a game. I can't quite describe it, because it looks pretty underwhelming at a first glance, but there is some magic in this game if you are willing to hustle a bit for it. The game constantly challenges you to make tough decisions and manage your time carefully. My favorite part is the wound system - ripping off a piece of my fur cloak and dragging myself to a branch on the ground to splint my broken leg just feels perfect. The animal AI makes hunting a constant challenge, and the wide variety of traps, weapons, and hunting strategies keeps it fresh even hundreds of hours in. On top of that, it just has this indefinable charm - it's a loveable game.

I can't recommend this game to impatient players or those looking for a "smooth" experience. Nor can I recommend it for those looking for a quick couple hours of fun. If you're like me and love simple looking games with unbelivable complexity under the hood, pick it up!

33026061.review:
I want to love this game. And there is so much to love about it. But 20 years of game development seems to have helped it little in the way on being fun for the player. I have played and enjoyed so many other rogue-like games such as Dwarf Fortress and Cataclysm DDA, so I'm fairly used to "so unfair its fun," but often Unreal World seems unwilling to indulge the user in fun. 

Combat is infuriatingly unfair. It is not difficult, per se, rather, your opponent has unseen and unfun advantages. I can accept that a highly trained red cloaked barbarian can easily take down my peasant forester. I cannot accept that I can sneak up to the red cloak, hit him with three arrows, stab him multiple times with a spear, and then get one shot and die instantly. The dev believes the game to be balanced, as late game armor and weapons make fighting trivial. But early and mid game, fighting is deadly for you. The dev also claims that NPCs do not have any unfair advantage. Tell that to a bear I shot in the head, whose wounds was "badly bleeding," and who was fading in and out of conscienceness (literally passed out twice), yet was able to run to me in one turn of combat, and proceed to kill me within 2 more turns.

"The world will surely teach one; if nothing else, than to walk slowly." Upon generation of a new character, you're greated with this Finnish proverb. And quickly, you realize how much the game wants you to act upon this proverb. The game is a slog. That may sound bad, but I love the thought of slowly working through a cold, rough game of Unreal World. I want to get to planting broad beans, crafting tonnes of trading goods, making friends with the locals, buying animals, and exploring the giant world. But at times, I find myself wanting something... more. Part of me wants to be self-sufficient in the world of Unreal World. It feels like it was meant to be so. Yet you are desperately tied to the small towns who are your only supply of metal tools and fishing nets (beside those you spawn with). Fustratingly, after 20 years of development, nets cannot be made, and the best tool you can create is stone. Salt, invaluable for curing food, must also be traded for. Seeds can either be spawned with, or traded for, but never found. All of these tie you to the town, which is fine, but limiting. 

I want to spawn in Unreal World, get lost in its woods, build a cabin, and create a life for my character all my own. In many ways, I want to lose myself to the Finnish woods. But instead, I find myself losing to bears that cannot be killed with head shots, enemies that can run faster then the flash (yet be "crippled") and controls that cause physical pain in my hands. Unreal World is so close to being a masterpiece, a true icon of video gaming. But I can't reccomend it without warning. The past 20 years have brought about many innovations, and some have yet to pass into the Unreal World.

32747101.review:
[h1]This may be the best game I've ever played.[/h1]

You may be wondering why I'm about to give this game such a glowing review when I have under an hour of play time on Steam. That's because it's free. It's been free on the internet for ages. Unreal World, developed by Sami Maaranen, and Erkka Lehmus, is a low fantasy roguelike set in Iron Age Finland. Of course, you know that from the description. To get to know this game, you need to immerse yourself in the world. And it's a big, complex world. URW has been updated regularly since its release in 1992. That's 25 years of frequent updates. The most recent version is 3.40, which just left alpha this year. I bought this game to support the devs, and it was worth every penny I paid for it. I'll do a quick rundown of pros and cons.

Pros: 
+Small game file - Since it's a simple roguelike, URW doesn't take up much space on your machine. You could probably run this on your 1990s IBM ThinkPad if you wanted to. 
+Better graphics than your average 1992 procedurally generated roguelike - Seeing as Sami has been updating the game for the past 25 years, it makes sense that it would look good. It's no Witcher, but it's better than Zork, or ASCII games.
+Great skills system - Skills govern everything from weapon skills to dodging, skiing, sneaking, building, cooking, trapping, fishing, forestry, and agriculture.
+Depth - The game is deep and complex. The game comes with its own encyclopedia (F1), and it's easy to sink hours upon hours into the game, discovering all the little secrets. For example, just yesterday I learned that sometimes, villagers who you help out will tell you the approximate location of buried treasure. That's better than 2 squirrel skins' worth of traded goods.
+Rich world - The world is procedurally generated, but with geographic features like lakes, rivers, rapids, crossings, mountains, hills, seas, cliffs, and forests and swamplands of all kinds, you're unlikely to grow bored of your environment, or run out of space to explore (The game world is huge!) Each culture has its own spheres of influence surrounding their villages, where you will meet people of that culture. (Different cultures are good at different things. For example, the Koivulaiset are good farmers and trappers, but poor physicians and herbalists. They are handy with flails.) You can learn all of this stuff over time just by playing the game.
+Seasons are awesome and add a great degree of "Freshness" to the game - Things are easy in the summer. Food is plentiful, and you can grow what you can't catch, hunt, or trap. It's easy to walk around, and you're in little danger of extreme temperatures. Winter is another story. If you haven't prepared for the long snows by the time the first flakes are falling, you may be doomed. The temperatures drop low enough to easily kill someone who doesn't have enough furs or shelter, the snow is so deep it slows you down and tires you out (Skiing is faster, and makes you less tired), and animals are rare. You probably won't stray far from your cabin. Winter really switches things up, and forces you to manage your time in the summer.
+Mods add additional depth to the game - The game isn't perfect. Sami and Erkka are just two dudes, so they can't put everything they want in the game (Though they always have plans to add more content.) This is where mods come in. 3.40 is very new, so people might still be tweaking their old mods to fit this version, but I can let you know what I play with. Buiodda's Crafts (Which includes some of the mods of Rain, another amazing modder) adds ironworking, bowying, clayworking, and weaving (courtesy of Rain.), among other things. Budz Brewing adds beer and berry wine to the game (It has mead, but that may need another mod to work, because I haven't seen any bees or honey.), as well as barrels, which are great high-capacity containers. For a list of some of the mods, visit https://www.unrealworld.fi/wiki/index.php?title=Mods .
+Just try it. - It's free! What do you have to lose? If you love the game, like I did, you might support the devs, so that they can keep working on this incredible project. Link to the official site below.

http://www.unrealworld.fi/

Negatives

- Not easy - This isn't really a negative, but something which players should keep in mind. At least, it isn't easy to a disgusting casual like me. 
- I honestly sat here for quite a while trying to come up with something which I actually don't like about the game, and nothing came to mind. I don't know whether that reflects on URW as a game, or on me as a reviewer. 

tl;dr: Incredible game, great creators, great mods, just challenging enough, free from Sami's website, please pay him on Steam if you like it. Please.

MY OLD REVIEW:
What a shame to have to leave a negative reveiw for this. It should've been the best game ever. A tribal-ear survival game with minimalistic graphics and over 25 years in development, with great depth accumulated over time? Yes, please! I really wanted this game to work out and was willing to forgive it a lot, but it just fell flat on its face because, apparently, it looks like in those 25 years nobody bothered to put any time whatsoever into a more intuitive and convenient UI or just improve the gameplay experience in general, other than adding more to the game's amazing depth. 

It started out with technical issues right off the bat. It took over 2 hours of research, manually installing VC++ distributables  of various versions to even get this game to run (apparently if anything goes wrong during the game's original distributable installation, it never tries to install them again and just crashes on every start without giving you any errors; not even deleting all game files and redownloading/reinstalling fixes the issue).

Having gotten past the technical stuff, I was excited to play. To say the user interface is clunky is to say nothing. You can do almost nothing with the mouse and menus. You're supposed to remember all the key shortcuts in order to play this. Want to drop something? Can't just go into inventory and drop what you see from there like a normal game would. You have to press "d" on your keyboard, then mark the item(s) in the resulting drop menu with "ENTER" and then when you are done selecting press "SPACE". Want to craft something? Press "s" for skills. Want to put on your mittens because they game tells you your hands are getting cold? Press "W". Pay attention, that's upper case W, because lower case w is reserved for selecting your weapons. The only way it could get worse is if you had to type in action words a-la 1985 games.

The game does a poor job of informing you of what's happening and stopping time accelleration, leading to unfriendly outcomes. The tutorial guided me through felling a tree and building a fire and, after giving me a fresh pike, asked me to cook it. The pike will be cooking for a few hours, it said, so why don't you go try crafting something? OK, I went to the felled tree, selected the woodworking menu, and tried to make some boards. No indication how long it will take, time accelleration kicks in. Three times through the process a bird flies over, and the game helpfully asks if I want to stop what I'm doing. Well, no, I have no bow and so no way to interact with it, so I keep going. Then, in very quick succession and with no indication other than pale text in the game log, I get hungry, the pike starts to smell like it's burning. I frantically cancel the action manually and go pick up the pike. It hasn't burned, but it has spoiled. How on Earth does a fresh fish spoil in the middle of grilling?! Whatever, let's eat some food we started with instead and go finish those boards. Time accelleration starts again until without any warning you collapse and eventually sleep. Wake up in the morning with fully depleted hunger and bar, and a red state of "malnourished" barely able to get up. This, after eating full the night before, right after the game tutorial told me I can go without food for a couple of weeks. Thirst, which the game warned about was critical, didn't even rise past half in all this time.

Now, I'm willing to put up with a ceratin level of junky UI and buggy mechanics from a game I like, but let's also not forget that this is a rogue-like. A bug or a dumb outdated UI decision can be the undoing of your character. As somebody on the forum wrote, they spent months building a house, then built a fire close to it and it just burnt down, leading them to rage-quit and abandon the game for a while. I can see stuff like that happening a lot in this game.

Now, it's undeniable that the game has a loyal following, so there must be a way to get past all this stuff and see into the good sides of the game if you invest enough time and effort, but in the time I got while still being able to refund, all I saw was a buggy, poorly designed and unplayable mess that belongs in the '90s where it crawled out from.

32228026.review:
I am mad. Sure, this game is good - sort of. I enjoy playing it, and have spent many hours playing it, but there are a few glaring issues which still make me so horribly upset that I cannot write a positive review.

The first, and foremost issue, is combat. In a sentence: Wow, it sucks really badly.

Let me be clear: the system itself for combat is quite cool! It uses body parts, different attack types, bleeding, various injuries... It's extensive, and very fun! In theory. In truth, trying to fight literally ANYTHING that isn't completely subdued in a trap is as fluid and balanced as Niagra Falls - which is to say, not at all. Unless you get a lucky strike early on in a fight, you are doomed to die as the AI lands nearly every attack (with at least glancing blows) and will eventually kill you or knock you out, whereupon you also die OR lose all your stuff. Let me give you a recent example. I made a character, high stats all around, good Strength and Endurance and Speed and Agility, good Sword, Spear, and Block skill, and chose the Bandits! start. I began with a Broadsword, which was brilliant! I waited, baited the bandits to a bottleneck in the trees, and combat began.

Only two attacks in and I had landed a solid blow on his neck with my broadsword. 'Huzzah!', I thought, assuming that would be the end of him - except, he kept attacking me. Yes, you heard that right - a man whose throat had been slashed (not a glancing hit mind you, a 'solid strike' with the Edge) by a SWORD continued beating me with his stick. He then conked me on the head with what is the equivalent of a god-damn mother fucking BRANCH and I was instantly unconscious. He took all my things and left me for dead in the wilderness.

What?! Are you kidding me? And that's not the first time! I have been MASTER level upon character creation with weapons, been given said weapons, and then tossed into the fray only to die to the first combatant I encounter (Human or Animal, it matters little to this worthlessly lopsided combat system) and be forced to re-start. I barely land any hits that are more than mere grazes unless the person is previously completely incapacitated, and even when I do they miraculously shrug off serious injuries or the fear of death and beat me like a punching bag. It's horrendous.

This is the main issue with this game, in my opinion - and with it being the only way to ever gain new items without literal in-game weeks or even months of grinding (hello, Craft Wooden Bowl option!) or what essentially boils down to RNG (here's lookin' at you, Trapping and Hideworking! Better hope you can find 12 OTHER Bear Hides that aren't Ragged or Harsh!), it's horrid. It's like soggy porridge laced with gravel, scumming up what would be a fine brunch otherwise. 

Tl;DR? Combat sucks because the AI hits almost everything and despite your skills and stats you are a bump on the log.

And don't even get me STARTED on how crass the food spoilage is. Yes, food spoils, this is true and by no means do I mean it should be removed. But, unless you are a hunting or trapping G O D, fishing is the only sustainable way to stay alive and gain food in the entire game, since Smoking, Drying, and Salting are arbitrarily hard and un-doable until certain requirements are met (Smoking requires you to have built a home or use an already-built home in a village, which is wildly inconvenient, Drying requires it to be WINTER SPECIFICALLY, and Salting means you need to trade the Driik (( yes only one tribe can provide salt )) and they charge you like it's their god-damn lifeblood). This leads to a life spent almost always with the 'I want to be a Fisherman' start, as to guarantee a Fishing Rod, as even large take downs like Elk and Bears will still spoil in a few days regardless of how quickly you eat. And once that's gone, well, good luck finding more, you poor sod!

Update: As I was writing this, I tried again on the combat thing. After landing two hits to the head (one even being a 'perfectly executed thrust to his skull!') of an enemy, I proceeded to never hit him again for literally 30 turns of combat as all my weapons broke in quick succession, he never died or fell unconscious from blood loss as getting a SPEAR TO THE HEAD WOULD DO, and I died. And then, after trying AGAIN, I missed an attack on an Unconscious opponent. What?

30849420.review:
Quel jeu...

UnReal World est certainement revenu au gout du jour grace à la mode des "survival games" mais était en son temps l'un des meilleurs jeux de roles existant (1992 et constante amélioration par ses createur).
Ne l'ayant pas connu a cette epoque, à mon grand désaroi, il reste encore aujourd'hui l'une des plus belle surprise indépendante que j'ai déniché sur steam.

Au prime abord on se dit houla ça pique les yeux... mais si on passe l'aspect vieillot du jeu on entre dans un univers complexe avec une interactivité totale avec le joueur.

Le jeu se passe dans un univers qui represente la Finlande il y a fort longtemps quand les tributs dominées le territoire (periode pouvant aller de la fin de l'antiquité à la fin du haut moyen age). L'objectif du jeu est de survivre dans cet univers hostile, se proteger du froid se nourrir et préparer les longs hivers rigoureux de cette zone du monde. Il faudra aussi vous defendre contre les bêtes sauvages (ours, lynx, meutes de loups ...) et encore plus dangeureux une tribut particulierement hostile qui vie en predateur de se monde et tue ou réduit en esclavage le Finlandais moyen qui, quant à lui, est pacifique).

Pour se faire vous aurez la possibilité d'utiliser toutes les ressources qui vous entourent.
Vous pourrez chasser de facon active en traquant vos proies, ou en posant des pieges.
Vous pourez pecher ou encore durant la periode estivale vous nourrir de ceuillette. 

En evoluant vous construirez votre petit village (voir votre famille) ou vous pourrez elever des animaux faire de l'agricukture. Le commerce avec les truibuts est important dans le systeme de survie car vous ne pouvez pas réaliser des objets qui demandent une forte specialisation artisanale. 
La part crafting du jeu est importante car tout repose sur la transformation de matieres premières en produits finis (cuisiner, traiter des peaux de betes etc ...) 
Vous aurez aussi la possibilité de mener un culte a l'esprit de la foret par des prière rituelle selon les activités.
L'aspect jeu de role est present avec des quetes que vous donneront des aventureirs sur votre chemin.

Le jeu est difficile avec un vrai challenge, La mort est definitive pas de sauvgarde ... Et oui le défi est là... le systeme d'action/temps est super bien pensé.
Que dire de ce bijoux si ce n'est que certaine major devrait s'inspiré de ce que faisait les gars dans les années 90 plus de fond moins de graphisme.

Il est clair que ce jeu méritrait un second opus avec une refonte graphique mais reste parfait comme ça.

30727450.review:
[b][i]UnReal World[/i] is a unique and remarkable addition to the roguelike genre.[/b] I played this for many hours with the free version before it came to [i]Steam[/i]. At times I feel like this is a slightly more 'zen-like' experience than many of its dungeon-crawling brothers, simply because there does not [i]always[/i] have to be a clear-cut goal of getting to the bottom of a dungeon or escaping something. In exchange for dungeons, you get the great Finland outdoors. Sometimes you just chill out and exist. But don't get me wrong, the learning curve is still quite steep and you will 100% always die on a long enough timeline. This is [i]Don't Starve[/i] for the hardcore (I write that with a loving nod to [i]Don't Starve[/i]). 

[i]The flavor of this title is potent, and very much its own thing.[/i] This does not play or feel like anything else out there, as far as I'm concerned. It can't [i]accurately[/i] be described as just some sort of 'different angle' or 'take' on another game. The obscure mixture of old-school artwork with, well, old-school real life images is weird, but after a while it becomes alluring. The text is well written. I like the 'online' in-game encyclopedia and deep lore. [b]You could get lost in this universe for a life-time and probably still not experience everything.[/b]

[b]Overall, I really have no "con's" to list.[/b] This is a classic roguelike that is a pillar of the community, and deserves recognition as such. The controls are awkward at first, for sure, but quickly you get used to them and actually like them (plus there are options for traditional roguelike controls). Like any roguelike worth its weight, you will explore, die, learn why you died - and repeat to hopefully make it further. You will have a good time.

[b]So go ahead - pick this up and get lost for an afternoon... Or a weekend... Or a lifetime.[/b] You won't regret it.

30539960.review:
"Only when the last tree is cut;
only when the last river is polluted;
only when the last fish is caught;
only then will they realise that you cannot eat money."
-Cree Indian proverb

This game is clever in ways most modern 3D survival games can only dream of. Sure, the graphics are dated and controls might feel overwhelming in the beginning, but behind the first impressions hides a truly spectacular survival experience in the forests of Iron Age Finland.

Unreal World utilises the mechanics that 2D world offers over 3D to give the player more realistic survival setting. 2D world can speed up the world around you when you perform tasks much more naturally than any game done in 3D could, and the game takes full advantage of this. The days in UrW are 24h, the year is 365 days. When you plant crops they aren't full grown in the next morning. There's also full 4 seasons in a Finnish year. During summer it's warm and the nature is blooming, but after a few months of sunshine it starts to get cold. And it gets really cold. If you are not prepared the winter can freeze you to death in a day and roaming in waist deep snow is exhausting. But even winter has its benefits. Animal tracks are easier to spot in the snow and food lasts for months before it spoils when it's -20c outside 24/7.

Animals in the Unreal World are dangerous, but not like in many other games where you'll be beating them off multiple times a day with your fancy swords. In Unreal World even the most dangerous animals, the bears will flee when they spot you 90% of the time, perhaps even more often. They might get curious, smelling your roasting food and stay nearby. Come night they might try to sneak in and steal your food. Specially foxes like to do that. Or they might eat your livestock if you have any. But most of the time they will attack you only after you have provoked them by chasing them, cornering them or by surprising them, sneaking too close. Almost any animal will attack you when cornered, an elk might kick you to the head if you give it no chance to escape.

Combat is terrifying. Any time you are attacked there's always a real chance your game will end there. This might sound like a bad game design choice. But in my opinion it makes much more sense this way. The player is not a super-human who could beat of 10 other people with ease. And if you lose in combat you will not wake up in your bed the next morning or something like that. You will be staring at the summary screen of your characters life, that has ended. Some special cases might leave you alive after you lose a battle, the robbers and friendly villagers. Robbers will take all your valuables and villagers will take away stolen property by force if you try to steal from them.

Unreal World is the most complete survival experience I have come across, ever. And the best thing is that the author still has ideas of what to add, even if the pace might not be the fastest.

Here's a few ways to end your life sooner rather than later in Unreal World, try to avoid:
-Throwing a rock at a bear when you are not prepared for battle.
-Walking on thin ice in the spring.
-Swimming with all your stuff
-Fishing with poor skill or poor tools
-Eating funny looking mushrooms or plants.

30366456.review:
If you enjoy inmersive roleplaying within a game, and making up your own story, and letting your imagination take over in place of visuals then this game is for you.  However, if you need animations on screen, rigid questlines, and giant battles then you will not enjoy Unreal World.  It plays very close to the adventure mode in dwarf fortress (just not with ascii graphics) and Im sure some inspiration definately came from dwarf fortress.  

When starting the game you create a character through stats and choosing a tribe/ cultural group.  If you explore the help manual with the f1 key then you can find some more information about each tribe.  One thing I really enjoyed was that most of the native tribes (the northern tribes) aren't especially fond of warfare, but are very much in touch with the land and the spirits.

After creating your character you get to pick your starting "story" which is thr scenario your character will start in.  Most of the time I end up using the unfortunate hunting trip scenario, very revenant like, but I did not survive being mauled by the bear.

What Unreal World lacks visually it makes up for in depth.  The survival mechanics are managable, but it is too possible to not realize that you hadn't packed enough food to last a migration south to warmer climates for the winter.  Also, combat is much more unforgiving (just as it is in dwarf fortress (can you see a theme yet?)) And what seemed like an easy fight can go wrong with a lucky blow to the leg.  The hunting system is my favorite by far!  Tracking, stalking, mix and repeat.  Very realistic, and Im speaking from experience as a hunter myself.  In other games you go look for an animal, you shoot it, and you have enough food for a little while.  Unreal World makes you earn it.  So you found an elk, got close enough for a shot with your bow?  Great, you have mortally wounded it, but it still ran away.  So you will spend the rest of the in game day following blood trails and tracks, and hopefully you find it again.

If you do not enjoy creating your own experience in a game then Unreal World is not for you!  End of story.  If you like dwarf fortress, or other survival sims than you will get many hours of enjoyment from yhis game.

First, the positives:
1)  Original and historical setting
2)  Excellent atmosphere
3)  Interesting and deep combat mechanics

That's about it, really.  There's a lot of negatives when compared to similar games.  But I have to give it a positive review for being so original, especially considering the time in which it was conceived.  My biggest gripe is that for a game that's been in development for about 30 years, there's surprisingly little content when compared to other survival titles that are flashier and prettier to look at.  The development is absolutely glacial in pace (puns, heh...).  Released to Steam in Feb 2016 and it's received only 1 sizeable update if I remember correctly.  While this isn't exactly a roguelike, one of the strengths of the genre is it's ability to do so much with so little.  I feel like UnReal World doesn't capitalize on this asset.  With that said, the game still feels complete and worthy of a purchase, but there may be better survival games out there.  At the rate this thing is being made, I wouldn't be shocked if the developer dies before he ever realizes his ultimate vision for it.

29876363.review:
While Unreal World is a pretty hardcore roguelike, it's also very enjoyable once you understand how it works.  The game is set in Iron Age Finland, and you must face the hardships that living in such an environment entails.  Your character has a variety of skills such as hunting, fishing, farming, foraging, running, swimming, woodcraft and firemaking as well as skills in various weapon types.  You'll need to use them well if you want to survive as long as you can as it's all too easy to find yourself running out of food because you didn't catch enough fish or you let that elk escape.  You can also trade with the numerous villages in the game world, but as there is no currency, you can only barter, so you'd better hope you have something they want.  Building a log cabin which will become your base of operations is something else you can, and should, do.  As this game is meant to be as realistic as possible, you'll find building it to be a time-intensive grind as you fall trees and haul them to the construction site, all the while keeping an eye on your hunger bar.  You'll be grateful for it once winter rolls in though.

Unreal World is a game that requires a little patience, though there is a reasonably detailed tutorial.  If you enjoy survivial games that reflect the gritty grind of primitive life, you will enjoy this.  The game is still in development, although updates are not very frequent.

Probably the most realistic survival roguelike out there. Actual methods of survival apply here. Hunt, fish, trade, and survive iron-age finland. Light mystical elements like incantations. Brutal hunger, thirst and fatigue mechanics.

29680917.review:
Don't let the graphics and outdated controls set you off. The creators of this game reached the epitome of wilderness survival.

You are allowed to start off as a member of several northern european tribes, excluding the raiders that are situated far to the east. From there, you are pick one of a dozen or so scenarios to start from, ranging from starting in a half-built house with tons of lumber and building supplies, to waking up on the ground injured, hungry, with only your knife to help you.

From there, you can do whatever you want. You can live as a hermit, fishing and trapping game and crafting supplies. You can be a wanderer and travel between the numerous villages on the continent, where you can buy skins, food, supplies, tools, or even livestock and dogs. You can spend days at a time tracking and hunting animals, hoping that you'll manage to get a new pelt by the end of the day.

I have never felt more free in a survival game. There is no lack of things to do, and due to its difficulty, you are always working, trying to get enough firewood for the winter, or getting enough pelts to make that new overcoat after you had to turn the last one into bandages.

The game runs entirely on keyboard commands, which can take several hours to get used to, but once you get through that, you are bound to have a gritty, stressful, frozen, and wonderful time in the far north.

28193560.review:
I've played this game since before it was on Steam, and I've always found it fun to play. Now, however, I can leave a review!

So, this game won't be for everyone. I can gush about it for hours, but it's important that you understand that if [i]I[/i] like it, that doesn't have to mean [i]you[/i] will. That's why I will start outlining the things that may make this game not fit for everyone.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

[list]
[*]The graphics are simple and have little merit to them. They're merely there to make the game accessible. If you have a problem with simple graphics, this game is not for you.
[*]The controls are not very good. Once again, they're just there in order to be able to control the game, and to play this you'll have to remember or look up a bunch of key combinations. Luckily, you can do this in-game. This'll become muscle memory after a while, but if you're starting out it can be quite difficult.
[*]The game has no difficulty curve. There is one difficulty, and while you have the merit of starting out with some useful stuff and you can delay winter by starting early in the year, you're going to have to learn how to deal with the game's challenges. And this game can be hard, especially if you're not sure what to do.
[*]The game can be a grind. You have to focus on both the long term and the short term, which often means you'll have to do the same thing for weeks on end in an effort to reach some long term goal, and especially early on you'll be restricted when you're just beginning to make a living for yourself.
[/list]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

[list]
[*]This game has great depth. While it's certainly possible to understand the game mechanics, there are always things that will surprise you are possible. As an example, I once got knocked in the eye while climbing a tree, and I was astounded that my field of vision was actually decreased by this.
[*]The game world is huge. It's not endless, but there is plenty of room to do anything you wish.
[*]There are a lot of interesting skills, and they're not trivial to master. From weatherlore to timbercraft to tracking, there's plenty of skills to spend your time refining and reap the benefits from.
[*]There's a lot of things you can build and do. You could become a carpenter who sells their crafts for food, or a hunter, who is self-sustaining but has to travel a lot. Each option is interesting and provides you with a new style of play, needing to focus on different things to be successful.
[*]Realism. Harsh realism. This game is not forgiving, and a single mistake can lead to a series of events that ends with you dying alone in a pit surrounded by wolves. There are of course limits to this, but a few of the things you will need to keep an eye on during your travels are temperature, thirst, nutrition, carrying capacity, wounds, disposition with the locals, time of year, state of your clothes, and quality of your tools and items.
[/list]

In the end, there's just a lot you can do in this game, and it's great to see your plans come together as you slowly build up resources, self-sufficiency, and social contacts among the locals.
The price of 10,99 is great, and the amount of content you'll get is certainly worth that price.
This game sets out to place you, on your own, in a harsh, wild land in the ancient North, and it captures that feel well. You'll often be struggling to survive, cold, undernourished, or low on supplies, with no traces of civilization for miles around.
This game is not for everyone, but if you've made it this far into the review and you're still considering buying it, this game certainly is for you.

27951401.review:
I was a bit sceptical when I bought Unreal World considering the graphics and since I had never even heard of the game before but the sceptisicm was replaced by awe and wonder how I had never heard of the game before. It's brilliant, realistic and the longest still supported game in history. 

The graphics is probably one thing that hold people back from buying it. But don't let the simple graphics fool you. Underneath it's a very advanced simulator and you quickly forget about it and you might even think the graphics are good after a while.

The sound is what's happening in the game world, you hear an owl? There is an owl close by which you can hunt. You hear a wolf? Make sure your sheep is brought inside for the night or you could wake up by the sound of grawls and bleats. No music that disturb the sounds of wilderness.

The gameplay is what you make of it, you could be a trapper, hunter, a fisherman  or a farmer and build your own settlement and much of the gameplay is ordinary chores of the day. You need to cook your food, check your traps, fish and so on. To build a house takes a fair amount of time and is nothing you simply errect over a day. 

I can't recommend this title enough for people that enjoy a true survivalist simulator.

Ich bin auf Unreal gestossen, weil ich in einen Artikel über TOP 50 der besten RPG's aller Zeiten gelesen habe, in dem auch Unreal gelistet war.

Als ich es dann ausprobiert habe, hat es mich dann schlichtweg umgehauen. 

Dies ist tatsächlich eines der tiefgründigsten und vielseitigsten "Sandbox" RPG's das ich kenne.

Die Geschichten die man hier erlebt sind während des Überlebenskampfes sind umwerfend.

Beim ersten Überlebensversuch bin ich im Winter in Eis eingebrochen und ertrunken,

Beim zweiten bin ich schlichtweg verhungert, weil ich nicht wusste wie man jagd.

Beim dritten Versuch haben mich Räuber überfallen und ich konnte schwerverletzt entkommen und mich zwei Monate auf den Beinen halten, bis ich dann das zeitliche gesegnet habe. Der Überlebenskampf war eines der spannendsten Erlebnisse die ich in einem RPG bisher hatte.

Die Geschichten die man hier erlebt sind absolut vielfältig (habe auch Erfahrungsberichte anderer Gamer gelesen und oftmals lachen müssen).

Kurzum....ich habe bisher jede Spielminute genossen.

Man muss sich nur auf die Grafik einlassen und die gefühlten 1000 Tastaturkürzel, aber dafür bekommt man eines der besten RPG's geliefert.

First game in five years:

I start as a Kaumolainen, I have a dog, I name the dog - "Musti", I find a village, I get some arrows and a bow, I go out in the woods to hunt, I see a lone Njerpez warrior, I sneak close to him, shoot him with my bow - miss, shoot him again - miss, he rushes at me, Musti attacks him, he stabs Musti, i wield a knife and try to stab him - I fumble and drop my knife, he stabs me a couple of times and I lose my consciousness..... 

I wake up - amazed I'm still alive, I'm bleeding badly, and i leave a trail of blood when i try to walk, I stop the bleeding and pick up my knife, I look at Musti - Musti has bled to death - bastard killed my dog, I follow the Njerpez warrior's tracks and find him sleeping under a tree, I shoot an arrow at him - hit, he rushes me, shoot again - hit, I take the knife and stab him, he falls down. I stomp and stab him untill he stops moving... He's dead, loot sweet loot. 

I go back to Musti and butcher him for meat - Musti tastes bittersweet. I go back to the village to lick my wounds and eat roasted Musti for a couple of days. 

I'm running out of Musti meat, I go back to the woods to find something to hunt, I find a stag, i shoot an arrow at it - hit, it escapes, i start following it's tracks and find it again, shoot again - hit, keep following, shoot - hit, it's slowing down, rush it, I hit the stag with a knife, it falls down, I kick it and stab it, it dies and I skin and butcher it, I go back to the village and trade stag meat for more arrows. Hmmm I better build a sauna. 

5/5

It's survive and thrive in this game, eat or be eaten. This World will eat you up and spit you out when you go in blind, and that's fun. There's barely no hand holding at all, no easier modes, just you and nature, and those warriors that kill you everytime. As a person who love RougeLikes and Survival games this hits me with love. 5 Realistic Food sources, -Hunting, Passive Hunting, Farm/Gathering, Fishing, and Trading

Replay value
Great Devs, -if you're not a evil or disrespectful person to them

*Controls

*Too hard

(Final Thought)
It's a truly a great game and I hope the devs of this game will keep this game great as always, and keep it a great place in my heart. Just Buy it, for a great experience and Hunger! It's a great price for $10.99.

After downloading and playing it I've re-purchased.

When not concerned about the time and using out of the game resources and tutorials and just treating the in game tutorial as something that gives random bonuses instead of something to focus on it's been a much better experience.

-=-=-=-  Original review -=-=-=-

The game seemed to have promise and I want to like it but the 'tutorial' is terrible.  It introduces tasks in the wrong sequence and doesn't let you work on the relevant task until you finish the preceding task.

For example to build a fire you need to chop down a tree but you can't do the task for chopping down a tree until you build a fire.  Once you build the fire you need to chop down another tree to complete the chopping down a tree tutorial.

It eventually tells you to catch a fish but every body of water I can find says that there are no fish available.  I can't sleep because it's constantly raining so I'm crawling around trying to find somewhere I can catch a fish so I can move on to how to build a shelter.

Tutorials should not be an exercise in frustration like the tutorial for this game is.  If the developers don't want to fix the sequence of events for the tutorial at the minimum they should allow the player to view all tutorial options and give credit as they are completed.

It appears that fish is a poor choice of first food types because it is so dependent on finding somewhere that the game will allow you to fish that you end up starving to death trying to find somewhere to get food.

While the game might get better as you get more familiar with how it works (my second game was less frustrating then my first game) there is a limited refund window on Steam and as poorly as the game is currently playing I don't want to exceed that window it in hopes that the game gets better.

25511832.review:
I don't have a ton of time on steam and still not as much as many people have on the version before steam, however this has to be one of the best rougelikes I've ever played and I still can't believe it isn't more popular. You can do almost anything in the game that you want and the sheer size of the simulation and procedural generation is crazy. Every map is full randomly generated, although certain factions will always inhabit particular areas as that is part of the game's history. (Thereis a full in-game encyclopedia to tell you about just about everything, from were each of the 9 dominant tribes live, how they live, and what tools and skills the use in their daily life) 

The creators have updated the game for a very very long time and are consistent, I remember stumbling on this accidentally like 10 years ago on their webpage and thought it was awesome. They mix in real pictures to simulate many of the events in the game and locations and if you look past the basic spriting, its a game that shines. The soundtrack is great and the theme song is played on a Kantele, which is apparently a Finnish instrument. They use a lot of their heritage in the game as it is based in the real world with Finnish mythological stuff thrown on top (but mostly in the form of rituals). You can hunt, fish, trade, fight, build, go bear grylls in Iron Age Finland, basically whatever you choose. 

Although it is not a super easy game in the beginning, it is rewarding once you figure out the controls and your basics. There are guides available online too that make it easier to start, or just figure it out by trial and error and look through your list of ancestors. It's not that expensive and you'll get more time out of it than AAA titles, except maybe Witcher 3, because damn that is a good, solid game. But this is cheaper, so get this.

25486027.review:
Summary - the best survival simulator, and without zombies!

Pros:
1. Amazing depth - food can give you food poisoning, wounds can kill you slowly if not treated properly, you can freeze, and the bear can kill you with one hit. It is as unforgiving as it is deep.
2. Really immersive - I love the setting, with all those lovely forests and lakes, wise sages, a touch of magic, and never knowing what might hide behind the corner and kill you, if you're careless.
3. Crafting - you can craft many items, build your own home, and given how long it takes, it really feels like a reward.
4. Great developers who keep adding new things and make the game even greater. 
5. Very detailed system of clothing and how it shields you not only from the enemy, but also from cold. 
6. Hunting is really challenging and rewarding.
7. Trapping is fun.
8. Mushrooms that can kill you slowly. Seriously. This game is that unforgiving. 

Cons:
1. Interaction with NPCs is not great.
2. You can't have a family yet.

25346907.review:
I really like the idea behind this game, and it's a good atmosphere, good approach to survival games. But there are some minor things that is just bad game design and it takes away a bit of enjoyment from the game. 

For example tracking. Normally when you walk through the woods you notice tracks of animals here and there. Some pine cones eaten by a bird, or a squirrel, or a mouse. Some droppings of a hare, or a fox. Now and then some tracks. Even an idiot can clearly see these signs of animals moving about a forest, even though an idiot may not recognize what animal left that tracks. In this game, I'm playing a max intelligence character with 40% tracking skill and after walking over half the map he didn't spot a single track anywhere. What's more, walking through the woods is not enough, I have to activate a skill EVERY STEP OF THE WAY. Come on. It's just tedious and not the least bit of fun. Just make it a toggle to track, which means pay more attention to the ground, and let movement cost slightly more or something. 

The crafting interface is also a bit clunky. I have a pile of timber and planks and twigs on the ground, but if it's not in my inventory I can't build anything, and I can't pick it up because I'm not strong enough. Like, wait, that's not how you build a house... Builders don't carry EVERYTHING THEY NEED for the house, they just go get one plank at a time. If it's in the adjacent squares, that should be enough.

And so on. But it is an enjoyable game. Just a bit surprising that it was developed for decades and still simple things to fix like what I mentioned are still in the game.

24737705.review:
So, back in 2006 I bought this crappy sandboxy roguelike from a finnish indie developer for the outrageous sum of $49. After a week of having my characters die in days from tree falling, bear mauling, and poorly planned attacks on way better armed enemies, I upgraded my computer and for the life of me could never figure out how to get a link to another copy.

Fast forward to 2016 and I found out that this game is still being developed (with way better graphics) AND a fully free version to try out.

As far as the game:
Brutal survival, a lucky hit from an enemy can down you and getting surrounded is an easy death. Every action is a risk/reward calculation.

Good health modeling and healing is slooooooooow. My current character is a few weeks into his life after a day one fight with 5 slavers and the wounds aren't even half healed (he's lucky to be alive, though.)

Being a turn based game, the wound penalties aren't bad gameplay wise. You get heavy percent based penalties to your actions, but the player isn't burdened with horribly slow walk/run animations or real time sleep due to frequent exhaustion.

World building and seasons are fantastic.

It still plays like a DOS roguelike with hotkey commands, but there is some mouse support that improves quality of life a bit.

Best $60 I ever spent on a game.

24561555.review:
Finland simulator Ca. 1000 AD

But in all seriousness, this game is simply amazing. The amount of detail, intricacy, love and care that has been put into this game continues to shake my very core. As someone (from Finland indeed) who enjoys outdoorsy life and camping in the wild, I have never found a more brutally honest representation of how simply awful life could be for people in past eras.

That's not to say it's 100% realistic, but it's damn well close enough for my taste and really gives you a feeling of accomplishment when you know that you are doing something farely realistic to have survived in that period.  This game has transformed what I thought would be a light intrest when I bought it to a full-blown obsession.

It has a steep learning curve, and it ain't pretty to look at (at first, this changes once you get used to it, and by that point the graphics become very comfy indeed), but my god(s) has this game recieved my attention since I bought it. It's become one of those games that I just can't stop wanting to play. I constantly want to pick it up, and once I have I can't put it down again before I fall asleep at my keyboard. I absolutely recommend this game, in all it's brutal beauty, and it absolutely deserves DOUBLE of the asking price in my humble opinion.

So buy this game, perkele, and make sure to have a handy book of finnish swears and insults ready for all those absolutely thrilling and chilling experiences!

24281544.review:
This is a one of the best all time survival, hunting, fishing, building, fighting, exploring, bartering, crafting, pretty much everything sims. Don't let the hours here fool you, I've put hundreds (maybe thousands) of hours into this game long before it got onto Steam. The game is fantastically replayable, which is good as you will be replaying it a lot when your characters die, over and over. 

I would not describe the game as brutal, since there are some starting scenarios that actually set you up quite well if you just want to get to a point where you're stable and can focus on building a house, crafting, and trading. But the game IS unforgiving. No matter how well equipped you are, you'll need to think twice about taking on a Njerpez warrior (even alone) or going after that bear you see across the marsh. One missed swing or shot by you and one solid hit from your opponent (especially if that opponent is a bear) can end you all at once. Or maybe just give you a little scratch that you can tend to while you're sorting through loot or tanning a bear hide to make yourself a nice winter coat. That unpredictability that faces all violent interactions within the game can put some players off, but is a huge draw to others like myself. And if you're looking at a game like this, you're probably one of those kinda of players anyway!

While the game has tons of content and an absolutely enormous, randomly generated world to play in, the one downside is that it suffers from something of a "late game" drag. I hate late game in the context of Unreal World since you can play for as long as you can keep your character alive, but when you've survived one full year and you're comfortable enough to sit for days on end at your homestead crafting or resting and not have to worry about feeding or clothing yourself, you'll know you've arrived at the "late game". However, once better interaction mechanics are implemented with NPC communities (something that is in the pipeline), this period will be vastly improved. In the meantime, what most players seem to do is pick harder scenarios, pack up and move, go on a really long expedition, or start taking on riskier endeavors (such as aforementioned bear hunting and Njerpez fighting. If you're worried your character has become to comfortable, remember there are always "fun" ways to live on the edge in Unreal World.

24020894.review:
I have seen this game over the years and never put forth the effort to even play it.  but steam shoved it in my face so I gave it a go.  What to compare it to?  Adventure mode in Dwarf Fortress is about the only thing close.  While DF is soo Deep with physics and minutia controls that the interface and commands keep 90% of the potential players away, URW has much lighter controls, but that is compared to DF, compared to pretty much any other game it still has alot of commands... but they are structured much better than DF, and only take about an hour to get a good handle on them (watch wildfirefly12's let play (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_JW9Zr0Yxs&list=PLUGuQn97METNsvmaro7R1qH5IFxHMXUFX) she gives a pleasant play through of a few characters, and ends the lets play with a massive attack on the hostile tribe (Njerps).  The letsplay will give you pointers to some good mods she uses and also a good walk through of the commands as she uses them, and certain things to watch out for while playing.

As to my handful of play throughs, most have ended by falling through the ice while trying to cross rivers or lakes, either too early in the winter or too late in the spring... listen for the ice cracking.  I do recommend starting a few characters that are purely combat and just go on a killing spree of people to get used to the combat and how to fight, it isn't difficult to issue commands, but it does take some practice/experience to plan each strike, and which weapons are better to defend with (let them attack at you while you counterstike their attacks)  Also your cumulative penalties need to be carefully monitored, rest when you need to and reduce your weight burden else you will just think the game is too hard, it isn't you are just literally stacking too much on your character.  it helps with making better quality goods.  Also start a a good quality cook.  you food will go further as each meal will be satisfying.  best starts for newbies are failed hunting trip and lonely settler as both will start you with a real ax, not a stone ax or no ax at all.

Last hint, don't build a fire next to your cellar, the heat from the fire will warm your cellar and make all the food in it go bad, LOL and 10/10 for that level of detail.
