23889760.review:
When I first saw the reviews for this game, I was really repulsed. People only have 10-100 hours logged in this game. It didn't make sense to me; the normal amount of time investment in roguelikes is entire years. I assumed they were casuals who collect Steam games and don't actually play any.
Now after 70 hours of playing myself, I understand why.
The game is too damn easy. With the character I'm currently playing, I killed a bear in my first ten minutes of starting the scenario, and now, only a month in in-game time, I'm powerful enough to slaughter the residents of two villages a day. 
And I fucking shouldn't be! I by no means have any plate armour or super weapons. I am a peasant just like them, yet they walk into me like I'm a meat grinder somehow and I leave each village with "shallow cut in right forearm" at best.

So, I guess with that being said, this is one of those vagina games for children that "can be hard if you deliberately cripple your character, ignore numerous game mechanics entirely, and always restrict yourself to shit gear" AKA Pokemon. And I ask people who do that sort of shit: Why? Why play games like Pokemon or UnReal World only to avoid a majority of the content--lest you make it too easy for yourself--instead of just playing a game that's inherently difficult? There's other RPG's out there where you'll actually be challenged just by playing the game normally and utilizing all materials and tactics. Play those and stop pretending this game is hard just because you purposefully break your character's legs to the point where you can't even cut a tree down. That's YOUR actions inciting challenge, not the game's.

The first fifteen-thirty hours make the game appear impossible. But honestly in retrospect, I really only struggled with it due to my not knowing how to distribute my time spent on various tasks. You'll lose characters to this confusion. Do not misinterpret this as challenge, it is only the overwhelming amount of skills and ways to gather food that are leading you to death. You'll grasp it all soon and realize it's mathematical boredom. Nothing will intimidate you. You'll have so much food you'll have to throw it away to make room for more food. I had one character with 400 pounds of food in a cellar and I didn't even bother removing it when it all spoiled. 

If in future updates they change it so that I'm no longer a walking meat grinder who sucks the life out of anything that moves as soon as it enters range, I would very much enjoy playing. One suggestion I have is to make there be 500% less settlements spawning. If there were only one or two within reasonable walking distance of the player, maybe I'd value them enough to not slaughter their sages and steal their livestock. This would probably be easier to implement than tampering with damage multipliers and everything else it takes to nerf or boost characters. 

I still recmmend the game despite writing nothing but complaints because it took me 70 hours to realize how depthless it all really is. The game maintained this facade that kept me fearful and thinking I was some chess master when I'd succeed in kills. It wasn't till I decimiated my 50th village that I realized "wait a minute. absolutely nothing is a threat to me, even when i'm practically naked and using only a handaxe".
Also, I respect the developer despite my major disagreements with some of his methods. You are living the dream, and I think you're a swell guy.
So, yeah. 10 bucks for 70 hours of fun? I don't regret this purchase in the slightest, though clearly I had expected this to be years of fun like other, better roguelikes (...that are all free. Ouch).

23886722.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]
It is a realistic survival simulator. It is a rogue-like. Starting from sticks & stones, build and trade whatever you need to survive the unforgiving Northern Europe. There are no classes, levels, hitpoints... just you, your survival skills, knowledge and pure nature as far as eye can see, and quite a bit more after that.

[h1]Gameplay Highlights[/h1]
[list]
  [*] It is turn based, it is played by mostly keyboard, but some actions are simplified with a mouse.
  [*] You can choose tribes for various initial bonusses to skills, and starting items, then use skills to train and develop them.
  [*] There are no limitations based on skills or item quality (although tasks require specific types of items). The end result, and how long it takes to get there varies by skills and item quality.
  [*] Damage modelled as wounds inflicted on specific body parts, and blood loss. 
  [*] Hunger and thirst are fairly realistic, in fact this game has the most realistic hunger and thirst simulation I've ever seen.
  [*] Objects and actions behave as expected. Recipes make sense. There are no mysterious crafting recipes like "wood + rock = hand gun"
  [*] The game is difficult. It will take a while to survive beyond the first week, it may even take a few tries to get to that point. Oh, and there are no guard rails. You can die within the first day.
  [*] Some items, including some common items, cannot be crafted, and must be traded for. This may initially be irritating.
[/list] 

Have you played roguelikes with keyboard before? Are tired of classic RPG elements like hit points and levelling and classes? Are you looking for a wilderness survival simulation? 3 Yes= Buy this game. 1-2 Yes = Download the free version from http://www.unrealworld.fi, see if you like it. If you do, consider buying it here to support the development.  3 No = Probably not for you, but who am I to say?

22883905.review:
(dont get irritated by my play time, i have been playing URW since long before it was on steam)

Finally i can spend my time again in the far north, hunting Elk, drying their meat, tanning their skin to craft some warm winter clothes. I tried farming once, but in early summer an elk ravaged my fields and ate everything. The spirits seem to prefer me living a hunters life instead.

The AI is especially remarkable with realistic animal behaviour. They roam through the land, depending on the season, the terrain, spirits' favour and chance. The world is much more complex and dynamic than in other survival games such as the Long Dark. 
There are loads and loads of plants. Dont know a mushroom because your herblore skill is too low? better dont eat it, you might get sick and die. Thank the spirits, there are also plants that help your body in a variaty of ways, some ease fever and help you getting rid of toxins. Or ease that flu you got after sleeping in the rain. Better know some. winter time? no plants for you then, except maybe some cloudberries that ripen extremely late in the year.

coolest crafting system i know. Want to smoke your meat because you cant eat the whole elk before it spoils? Well, you need a smoking hut. fell some trees, big ones. Make logs from the trunks, build walls. split some trunks into boards, make a door. get smaller trees and boards for the roof. a window, if you are fancy. For each step you need an axe. while it is possible to fell trees with a flimsy stone-axe, you better have some nice big axe (different axes are ideal for different work) or this will take a while...
 collect a whole bunch of stones to build a stove. get firewood and smoke it up. dont forget some tying equipment to hang the meat from the roof (craftable from clothes or hides). And then the meat will taste terrible because your cooking skill is too low =) 

A Bear mauled you? well this game has the most complex system of injuries i have ever seen in a game. if he just broke some ribs, lucky you. Maybe your legs are total waste and you cant stand up. good luck hunting now, you better have some emergency food stache to last you until everything is healed. Got a nice warm bear fur coat? good for you, but without gloves you'll get frostbite on your hands in winter. Better make a fire and warm yourself up regularly. You met a raider with a cuirass and your weapon is rather flimsy? aim for the legs and run! more than a dozen different zones of your body can get injured with different effects an armor parts realistically cover different parts. Different materials protect differently against point (e.g. spear, arrows), blade(sword), impact (club, reindeer hooves) damage and cold. bleeding is seperately discounted for. better have a bandage or you will bleed out, good if you know the blood staunching prayer.

awesome game and great support, too! for example there used to be a rare issue with the game not starting up on ubuntu. posted on the forum, the developer replied quickly and fixed it. The fix is coming in the next update and in the meantime he even provided beta access to the fix.

The community has a forum, a wiki and lots of friendly, helpful people you can ask if you like spearfishing but keep starving or if you are wondering where to find herbs to help dresssing wounds. Or just go and explore the unrealWorld yourself!

22093880.review:
"What the hell is this crap?" My first impressions of the game; looking at the trailer and screenshots. 

I decided to randomly look at a video of this game being explained. Before I knew it I was slightly interested. 

My slight interest and curiosity got me to download the free version of this game and give it a good college try. After about an hour I knew this was something special. Something I could play for years if not for once in a while. 

You are in control of a tribesmen or women of sorts set to survive in the great iron north. You can customize your starting story which impacts your starting gear and situation respectively. You can also customize where you start and whether the tutorial is active or not. From there is up to you create a marvelous adventure filled with peril, exhaustion, starvation, infection, and whatever else might kill you. 

The game mechanics make sense and feel realistic. Chopping a tree down with a knife takes hours unlike using an axe, chasing down a reindeer or badger is unlikely, etc. It’s not perfect but it works. 

This game kind of reminds me of a ‘create your own adventure book/board game’. Time progresses as you perform actions and move around the world. This gives you time to think about your next action. Do you try and sneak up on that wild pig or do you chunk this rock on the ground at it? Knowing that if you miss it’s probably going to get away. Should I eat this spoiled food knowing it might make me sick? 

Death is permanent so make every choice count! 

Every action performed is checked against multiple stats. Reminds me of the old DnD days. Makes the world feel more immersive and the combat feel richer. You want to throw that spear? How fatigued are you? What’s you skill in spears? Are you injured? How far away is the target? I don’t know all the exact stats but I know there is a lot going on in the background for everything you do. 

I recommend that you just watch a couple video and try it out for yourself. Download the free version at their website.
 If this sounds good to you then you owe it to yourself to give it a good college try like I did. 

I will leave you with a brief adventure that I had in the Unreal World… 

Alone, cold, and starving I come across a lonely reindeer in the middle of a vast frozen forest. He doesn’t notice me so make a slow approach. As I approach I snap a small branch beneath my foot like an idiot which alerts the reindeer to jump to attention. It’s now or never. I draw and shoot my bow. The shot is steady and accurate but the reindeer is already in motion. The arrow penetrates just below the reindeer’s shoulder. It takes off into the dense woods. I follow. After a short while I start to lose sight of it and I am relying on my tracking ability alone. Tracks and blood keep me focused. As night beings to fall I start to loose site of its trail. It’s getting dark and I am starting to lose hope. My stomach growls and I begin to shiver. The cold is taking a hold of me I am beginning to fail. Then I hear something to my south. A yell of an animal. Do I continue on or follow the sound? I hear the yell again. After losing complete site of the reindeer tracks I decide to follow the sound. After about 10 minutes of travelling south I see it… It’s the reindeer I shot earlier. It nearly doubled backed on me. It’s injured, crippled and fatigued. “You’re mine now!” I draw and fire my bow. I am so fatigued the arrow hits the tree next to it. Again! I draw and shot my bow. The arrow flies true and I hit it straight in the neck; blood rushes out. It slows and after a few steps staggers then passes out. I approach and finish the job.
I take a moment to rest but I am too cold to stay still for too long. Night has fallen and I need to rest. I quickly gather some branches and firewood and make a fire. The warmth of the fire gives me a second wind an I decide to skin the animal and butcher some of its meat. I am so hungry I feast on it raw like a ravenous dog. Its late, taking satisfaction of a good kill I decide to sleep for the night. Unfortunately the fire goes out in the middle of the night and I awake in the early hours of the morning chilled yet again. I hear something approaching... I take a moment to scan my surroundings and notice my reindeer has been feasted upon. What could of done this? A dog? No... A bear. As I turn I see the bastard himself. I take a step back and it approaches. I draw my bow and take the shot. My shot is steady and true puncturing the bear in the front of his chest. It’s not enough. It becomes enraged and begins to charge. Before I can react It swipes its massive claw and gashes my arm and chest wide open. I fall back… I reach for my knife... It finishes me off with a mighty blow. 
Hugh Glass would of been disappointed... 

This is just one of my wonderful adventures. Many more await you in the Unreal World. 

9 bear tracks out of 10.

21861010.review:
Before I start, I just need to add: [b]you can download this game for free from the official UnReal World website![/b] The free version is practically (if not entirely) identical to the Steam version. Even if you're totally enamoured with this game by the looks of the descriptions and reviews, I still urge people to play the free version before grabbing the Steam one. Once you've given it a shot, you can make a much better decision on if you want to drop money on it. I told myself that if I played the free version for longer than eight hours, I'd buy the Steam version even if I never boot it up again. I clocked about ten hours, bought it on Steam, then continued to play it for however long it says I have at the top of this review.

I really love this game. It's deep, but I've never felt truly lost; when you make a character, you can pick to have a goal-orientated quest system that teaches you how to play. This ranges from 'This is how you drink water, you [i]gigantic idiot[/i]' to building your own house and trading for animals. Once you've grasped the basics, the game opens up as the survival roguelike it aims to be. If you want to know all the cool mechanics that come with the game, the other positive reviews go into passionate detail about what makes the game great. To avoid clashing with people who have literally hundreds of hours of gametime over me, I'll instead relay something that's unique to me; an in-game story.

Fur is really important in UnReal World. It's valuable, it's useful, and it'll stop you from freezing to death when Snow Hell decides to pay a visit. Unfortunately, being a total newbie at the game, the only hides I can get are from squirrels, hares, and ermines. Not very prestigious. The only big hides I had managed to score was one of a bear and an elk, and that's because they fell into a pit trap I set up and became a sitting duck for my volley of arrows. Basically, I'm a bad hunter.

One day I'm out in the snow in my bear fur clothes, checking my pit traps to see if any more suckers have taken pity on my awful hunting skills. The traps are on the border between a mire and a forest, set up to channel and capture any animals walking from one area to another. This time, I noticed a wolf on the world map standing in the mire, so I zoom in on the action to see what's going on.

Turns out, it's not a wolf. It's a [i]pack[/i] of them.

At this point of the game, the most dangerous thing I've successfully managed to hunt (that wasn't sitting in a pit and woefully awaiting death) is a fox. All the animals I've come across are basically 'let's see how close I can get before it runs away at the speed of light'. The wolves didn't do that. They decided that I'm up for dinner. They charge at me ("What? Animals [i]attack[/i] you in this game?!") and suddenly I'm reaching for my bow. I thought I was a goner, but it turns out that shooting an arrow into the shoulder of a charging wolf is a good deterrent (who knew?). It became a game of scoring a single wound on each attacking wolf to scare them and make them flee. I scored a particularly good hit on one wolf, and I chased down its limping self and attacked its head for a kill. Skinned its fur and butchered its meat and fat. Good stuff.

That's when I discovered why wolves were even here in the first place; lying in the middle of the field was a wolf-torn elk. I approached it and checked the hide, and was surprised to see the wolves hadn't mangled it beyond recognition. It was about a quarter of the way through skinning it that I realised the wolves were still around -- just keeping their distance. I decided to grab the skin and forget the butchering, get out while I still could. I didn't need the meat, the fur was the real gold here.

So I walk home with some wolf and elk fur under my arms. The total sum of the furs I had back home came to something like 8lbs; the fur I was carring totalled 30lbs. A good catch! I set the wolf fur down and use its fat from the butchering to tan it. I then set the elk fur down and -- wait! I didn't butcher the elk! I don't have any fat to tan it with! 20lbs of fur was threaning to go rotten on me if I didn't find a solution, and fast.

I dumped the fur in my cold, 'please don't rot on me' cellar and made a return to the elk. Turns out, so had the wolves, and they had regained their courage. Some nasty nips later, I decided my life wasn't worth some fat and fled.

I looked up about the tanning process to try to find alternatives for my elk fur. Turns out, you don't [i]have[/i] to use fat. The skinned barks of alder and rowan trees work just as well. Big problem; I lived in a gigantic forest of pine and birch. So begins the race against time to find an alder or rowan tree before my goldmine attracts flies rather than merchants.

So I'm darting around the world map, cursing every pine and birch that I see. That's when I find a herd of reindeer milling around. I decided to try my luck, so I zoomed in and took a less-than-hopeful shot at the nearest one, expecting a total miss and all the reindeer to flee. It hits. Fire off a second arrow before the victim has a chance to run. Second one hits.

Oh crap. So this is what hunting feels like.

The reindeer has been so badly hit, it's practically crawling its way across the floor. I catch up with it and start trying to unload arrows into its head. My aim is so bad that it ends up hitting the shoulder, body, and even one hit on the knee, at which point I reprimanded UnReal World for its poor choice of meme references. It was around the time I decided to equip a javelin and start poking its head that my character falls asleep. Turns out, fighting wolves and lugging fur across a continent really tires a man out. Who knew?

I awoke with the reindeer nowhere in sight. I followed its tracks and found it only a short run away, still desperately trying to crawl its way to freedom. I started poking at its head with the javelin until it dies, skinned it, made sure to grab the fat this time, and recovered the arrows I had fired. The fat of the reindeer was enough to tan its own hide, but not enough to tan the elk's. The hunt for the tree was still on.

I read up on alder and rowan trees, and found out that they mostly grow in and around villages. So I poked my head into the local village and -- sure enough -- sitting in the middle of the field all proud of itself was an alder tree. The villagers were probably weirded out to see a man walk into their village, cry 'YES!' and then begin frantically carving the bark off of one of their trees. I didn't care. Elk fur was back in fashion, baby.

So that's how I went from Small Game Extraordinaire to sleeping in the furs of a wolf, elk, and reindeer, all because I decided to go check my traps for a bit. My bear fur clothes had some nasty wolf bites in them and I had sufffered a few nasty scratches myself, but I could probably line the entirety of my house in fur now. It was about this time I realised that maybe, just maybe, UnReal World is an awesome game and that I'm glad I got it.

Stay safe in the cold North, folks!

21771818.review:
edit: I initially gave this game a negative rating, but as you can see, I'm now 40+ hours into the game, so I've now changed it to positive.

The reason for the initial negative rating is the rather-unfriendly UI. There are a myriad of keyboard commands you need to remember by heart. Using a mouse as input is not an option, everything is done strictly by keyboard. I'm the kind of gamer who likes to sit back and relax in my chair while clicking on my mouse, rather than hunch over the keyboard in an upright position, so I wasn't pleased in the beginning. The dozens of keyboard commands are difficult to remember and will force you to consult the "help" page every so often.

However, if you can tolerate this, Unreal World becomes a beautiful sandbox game. You can do whatever you want, whether it be to become a farmer, hunter, lumberjack, fisherman, bandit, serial killer etc. The main "goal" is to survive winter, which is harsh and deadly, so most of your time will be devoted to hunting and gathering food, and building a suitable shelter for the cold season. How you approach this is up to you. 

My main complaint (besides the unfriendly UI) is that the game world can feel lonely at times. At present, you're not able to marry anyone or have kids. You do have the option of hiring adventurers and workers, but they will only stay with you for a short time and then leave. You can't move into a village or improve it. The game makes you feel like you're an outcast with no friends or something. You can almost call it a hermit simulator. 

Overall, though, I find the game enjoyable. If you're into survival or roguelikes, UW is a very good choice.

21760005.review:
Have you ever wondered what being a Finn was like before the invention of alcoholism, anime, severe depression and murdering Russians? Well now, through the magic of computer roleplaying, you can at last find out!

This game is a pretty innovative blend of roguelike and survival simulator that dates back to several decades before the current survival game craze. The presentation and interface are true to that era, and so really shouldn't be a hindrance unless you're a millenial casual babby, in which case I congratulate you on managing to read this far without losing interest and playing with your smartphone, you little shit. 

The only area where this doesn't really hold is with certain repeated commands - putting down several fishing nets in succession involves a number of awkward key combinations, and the process of chopping down trees and hauling them to a location (which you WILL need to do if you want a house) will inevitably strain your fingers to the point where you will certainly come to sympathize with your likewise strained and fatigued character.

Besides that, the graphics are charming and effective - the sprites stand out, look good and tell you what you need to know, and the menus are decorated with quaint images of Finnish cosplayers in their natural habitat.

But enough about that nonsense! You want to hear about gameplay! The areas where this game really excels are its depth, realism and immersiveness. You begin play at a season of your choice, either in the wilderness or in a friendly, desolate or hostile settlement, depending on the starting scenario of your choice, equipped with either very little or nothing at all to help you weather the oncoming trials. From that point on, you have just one overarching goal: survive.

This isn't nearly as easy as you might think - not because everything is trying to kill you (in fact, the opposite is more likely to be true), but rather because getting the necessities of life is [i]hard[/i]. Hunting, for example, requires that you first find prey - which involves a great deal of fruitless wandering and scouring the land for tracks. You might follow a fresh and promising trail to the point where you're only a hair's breadth away from your quarry, only to have it suddenly go cold, prompting profound disappointment. If you do find prey, your problems only multiply, as you then have to make a decision - do you close the distance and risk spooking the game in order to get a better shot? Or take the one you have, and risk missing to the same effect?

Managing risks and resources is in many ways the core of the gameplay. You have to choose not only how to conduct your activities, but which activities to embark on, as each have their associated risks and rewards. A hunt is likely to fail, can be dangerous, and is wont to leave you far from home and exhausted come night time. Fishing is safe, but consumes large amounts of your time and might return nothing at all, or an insufficient catch. There are no sure bets, however, and you'll inevitably have to go all in at some point. Sometimes you'll fail. That's just life.

Likewise, every activity has its associated costs. Not necessarily in resources, but always in your character's time and energy. Building a house will give you a leg up, but chopping down trees and hewing logs is hard work that's sure to leave you with an appetite, and to make it worse, all that time you spent doing that was time you didn't spend acquiring food. Consequently, much of the earlier game is an exercise in building a big enough stockpile to be able to do more time-intensive work without worrying about what you'll eat tomorrow. This is difficult, as the most easily acquired foods (fish and meat) spoil rapidly without some means to preserve them, and even if you do get lucky enough to kill an elk early on, there's no way you can eat all the resultant meat all by yourself before it will spoil.

Still, though, overcoming all of those challenges as they come at you brings on a sense of elation like little else in video games. Sure, half of it might just be dying in the cold and worrying about tomorrow's meals, and sure, the Njerpez will kill your favourite dog, and sure, you might acidentally give your pants away for a handful of peas, but everything becomes worth it when you can sit down and look with pride upon your big house, blooming fields and cellarful of dried meats. It's an extremely immersive game, equal parts harsh and rewarding, and frighteningly easy to get lost in. There's far less cannibalism involved than I remember from the last time I played it, but I would still highly recommend it if you're into deep and immersive sandbox RPGs.

21712729.review:
UnReal World

24 Jahre in der Entwicklung und von einigen als
das "Beste Survival Game" betitelt.
Da kann man schon einiges erwarten oder?
... nein leider nicht!

Nach 24 Jahren ist UnReal World praktisch inhaltsleer!
Die Entwicklung hat sich auf ein paar wenige Features
konzentriert aber es ist leider kein rundes Spiel daraus
geworden.

Crafting:
Man kann lediglich eine handvoll Items selber herstellen.
Holzarbeiten und Leder/Fellarbeiten vielmehr gibt es nicht.
Und da auch nur wenige Rezepte.
KEINE Töpferei, Metallverarbeitung, Steinarbeiten oder 
Knochenarbeiten, Weberei, Köhlerei, Brauen/Keltern/Brennen ...
Man kann sich nicht mal eine Angelrute, Fischernetz oder
Speer selber herstellen! 

Building:
Beim Building (Hausbau) gibt es sogar noch weniger
Möglichkeiten als beim Crafting. Man kann eine Blockhütte
bauen deren Größe man selber variieren kann. Es gibt keine
Häuser aus Lehm, Bretter, Stein, Ziegel, Stroh ... 
Für die Blockhütte gibt es genau 4 Einrichtungsgegenstände.
Sitzbank, Tisch, Bett und Feuerstelle, das war es, mehr gibt es nicht.
Keine Regale/Kisten/Schränke, Kein Räucherofen, Kein Keller
in der Hütte, Keine Werkbank, Keine Dekorationen, ...
Neben der Blockhütte gibt es noch 2-3 andere Bauten,
wie einen Outdoor-Keller, Unterschlupf oder Zaun.
Lustigerweise gibt es zwar Zäune aber keine Zauntüren.
Kauft man sich ein Tier, so muss man mit dem angeleinten
Tier über den Zaun klettern um es in denn eingezäunten
Bereich zu bekommen.

Survival:
Positive ist hier erstmal anzumerken, dass es ein deutlich 
"""realistischeres""" Hunger/Durstsystem hat als viele
andere Spiele. Nebendem Hunger gibt es auch eine 
Ernährungsanzeige. Man stirbt als nicht direkt wenn
der Hungerbalken voll ist sondern wird schwächer!
Leider ist es aber sehr leicht an Nahrung zu kommen,
da die Fischerei übermächtig ist. Das Trapping mit 
Trap-Fence liefert auch viel Nahrung. Man kann auch 
ein paar Tiere halten allerdings brauchen diese
kein Futter oder Platz zum grasen und man kann sie
nur melken oder schlachten. Schafe können nicht
geschoren werden und Tiere vermehren sich nicht meines
Wissens nach. Eine Farm kann man auch anlegen.
Weiterhin muss Nahrung auch verarbeitet werden
um sie haltbar zu machen oder man kann sie zubereiten
um den Nährwert zu erhöhen. Ißt man verdorbenes
Essen kann man dadurch vergiftet werden.
Es gibt noch Verletzungen, Erfrierungen und Krankheiten.
Alles im Allem ist es aber sehr leicht zu überleben
außer man macht es sich künstlich schwer.

Exploration:
Besonders viel zu Entdecken gibt es leider nicht aufgrund 
der fehlenden Inhalte. Man kann zwar bei anderen
Stämmen oder reisenden Händlern Gegenstände kaufen,
welche man selber nicht herstellen kann, wie Waffen,
Rüstungen und Werkzeuge aus Eisen aber viel ist es
auch nicht. Darüber hinaus wird auf der Karte angezeigt
in welchem Gebiet man welche Stämme antrifft.

Combat:
Hier hat man einige Arbeit reingesteckt. Es gibt 
verschiedene Trefferzonen, verschiedene Rüstungen
bieten verschiedenen Schutz an verschiedenen Stellen.
Man kann selber entscheiden wie man die Waffe benutzt
und aufwelches Körperteil man Ziel. Auch über die Abwehr
von feindlichen Angriffen kann man frei entscheiden.
Es ist aber bei weitem nicht so komplex und tiefgründig,
wie es sich anhört!

Trading:
Das Handelsystem funktioniert auch nicht besonders gut.
Es gibt keine Preisunterschiede in verschiedenen Regionen.
Bei Stämmen die viele Felle besitzen sind Felle genauso 
viel Wert wie bei Stämmen die kaum Felle besitzen zum Bsp.
Als reisender Händler kann man sich seinen Lebensunterhalt
nicht verdienen. Dafür bekommt man aber seltsamerweise
für die einfachsten Sachen ziemlich viel. Ein paar Bretter die
schnell gemacht sind, lassen sich gegen große Mengen
Vorräte (Nahrung) eintauschen.

Endgame:
Es gibt kein Spielziel oder wirkliche Storyline.
Es gibt ein paar Aufgaben, wenn man die Option
am Anfang wählt. Ansonsten heißt es wieder
Überleben bis die Langeweile dem ganzen ein
Ende setzt und das passiert aufgrund mangelnder
Möglichkeiten schneller als man denkt!

Unterdem Strich ist man wohl mit Cataclysm Dark Days Ahead
besser bedient, wenn man die Monster deaktiviert und in
der Wildnis lebt.

21683556.review:
I was woefully ignorant of this game for many years, which is sad, because this is THE game I always imagined being able to play one day.

This is a game with such depth that it could only be an "indie" game. 3D rendering, fancy production, developer time-tables... all of that Big Name Developer stuff would make creating a game like this completely impossible.

UnReal World is a procedurally generated (yet large and persistent) world, inhabited by incredible A.I. There are numerous tasks always available for you to do, and the objective is simply to survive. But almost inevitably: you won't.

Your character struggles mostly against nature (and the occasional bandit or warrior). The weather, the ice, the BEARS. Go fishing, go hunting, go trading. Make tools and weapons and traps. Whatever you think you could do in an Iron-Age Scandinavian forest, you can do it in this game, with astonishing attention to detail and realism.

The animal A.I. is amazing. Wolves split and converge over long-distances with their packs, howling for communication. Kill the biggest reindeer in a pack (the leader) and the other reindeer will become aimless until they're picked off by other prey. 

Combat, while not action-based, has a cold realism to it unlike anything I've seen. Your life isn't measured in "Hit points"... Rather your body, your limbs, your blood, your senses: they can all be attacked and taken away from you -- or you can take them away from your enemy. One hit in the right spot will debilitate you. Game over. But its a death that will make you smile. Dying is a part of nature, and a part of this game. Fight against it, but realize that its what makes your character's adventure... complete.

Hunting in this game is a challenge and never a guaranteed success. You, the player, as a person, need to learn the value of patience and deligence. But when you finally manage to track down your first elk or stag through vast reaches of forest, until at last the animal is too fatigued to run anymore... there is NO "kill" in a videogame I've found as satisfying as this. Yesterday I got really lucky, and chased a panicked reindeer that injured itself trying to scale down a cliff -- but when I finally caught up to it, a wolf had half-eaten its corpse, ruining the precious fur and making off with some of the meat.

Smoke/Dry the meat, tan the skin, feed your dog, and donate a cut of meat to the "gods" for letting you live another day. Work on building your cabin, or preparing the cold soil for future agriculture. There is so much to do, and it is all vital, well-designed, brilliant. This is a brilliant one-of-a-kind game that throws you into a real world like no other game I've ever played. There is no game I would more enthusiastically urge people to try. I am so happy this game has come to Steam, thus coming to my attention, and I have never been more happy to give a developer my money (thank you, Sami). Try this game.

21678513.review:
I must admit that I like roguelikes and survival games and I like to try out many of them, I also frequently buy roguelikes on steam, but usually I play them for a couple of hours and then don't return to them. They might be interesting and fun, but only in few cases I really get hooked. I have played the steam version of URW for only 10 realtime hours (44 ingame days), but they flew by like nothing and I feel like I will  keep returning to this game.

Like with all games, I would only recommend the game if the setting appeals to you, which is based on stone age Finnland with all its harshness and mythology. Just watch the steam launch trailer, if it seems interesting to you, it might be worth buying this game. You have to be prepared to do some reading, there is a lot of ingame lore and many things you need to know in order to survive. The use of the online wiki is not required, there is a tutorial and an ingame encyclopedia, but still the wiki can be really helpful at times. Also, you will need to learn many keybindings and how to operate the game by keyboard. That is certainly not a game for the totally impatient, they won't survive long.

But that does not mean that the game is boring, there is a huge world waiting for you to be explored. And there is always something to do, there are different ways to keep your belly filled, as a hunter, fisher, farmer, trader and so on, but no matter which career(s) you choose, you won't be able to lean back. I haven't played a survival game yet which felt so realistic. I felt so happy when after few days of unsuccesful hunting, after many animals escaped me (despite following their track), and near starvation, for the first time I finally managed to kill a stag. I butchered it and cooked the pieces, which fed me for several days, until they got spoiled. I wasn't wise enough to smoke/dry them or to build a cellar for storage. I learned from it and my character became really promising, until I made the mistake to fight a couple of robbers, which led to an early death when I failed to treat my wounds. The game tells its own stories and even though the graphics seem horrible, the immersion is greater than in any other game I have played so far. I am looking forward to my next character and if he will be able to survive his first winter.

Tldr: In no other game I felt so happy and thankful to the gods of nature for being able to live another day.

21653311.review:
UnReal World is an engaging survival roguelike with an amazing amount of depth. 

You're alone in the wilderness set in the iron age of finland. You create a character from scratch with tons of skills at your disposal. The player is given a lot of freedom and tools which grants a lot of variety. You can play vastly different and try various survival tactics in order to overcome nature and it's threats. Be a fisherman, farmer, hunter, gatherer or a bandit. You're given the choice.

The world itself is vast and filled with tons of items, creatures, immersion, lore and danger. It's very intricate and engaging with a great amount of detail. Every task that action that you perform has consequences and keeping your characters alive is really a challenge, furthermore the entire game is designed in a realistic way which only enhances the immersion. From fishing to hideworking or combat, everything is rough and has detail. It's a engrossing and hostile world.

A great aspect is the interactive story, despite not having a full blown campaign. You can chose from a variety of character backgrounds which vastly changes the start of your adventure. Start as a well equipped hunter or fisherman but if you're up for the challenge you can play as a runaway slave that is being hunted. You make your own story and it's done with such detail that you feel really immersed. Even though the minimalistic graphics aren't that advanced, the presentation is solid. The small amount of songs and sound effect will still grab your attention, as for the rest the text provides enough flavor to really make you feel like this lonesome adventurer. This is pretty much standard for most roguelike though but this theme really resonates with me compared to other dungeon crawlers.

The interface and controls are somewhat unintuitive but once you get used to it, it's really not that much of a deal. It might be a hassle at first to browse through the various menus but it's all set up in a reasonable fashion. That might be the biggest issue about this game, also there aren't many sound effects but it's still solid enough.

Overall this is a very lovely game and crafted with such dedication, if this type of game doesn't appeal to you. You will probably get frustrated and not really enjoy it. But if you do, you will be rewarded with a great survival game that actually makes you think about provide a good challenge, while having a strong theme with a realistic tone.

Definitely worth the price. Even if you're not sure about this game, you can still download it for free on the official website.

21614411.review: If Dwarf Fortress interested you but your bounced off the complexity and the learning curve of that game then this game might interest you. There is a free version the creators website, but it is an older version. The latest version on steam has a revamped graphics and new features. The new graphical upgrade does look better. You can zoom out and see much further or zoom in close to your character. This game may not have eye candy graphics but its gameplay pulls you in. Its a survivalist game where the details can kill you. You have to think about what you are going to do next, based on your characters condition and the environment, how much food you have, fatigue and sleep etc. Merely eating any food wont in the long run do you any good if you stick to fish for example because your nutrition will suffer, which means you get fatigued faster. You can trap, track and hunt game. But its not easy, often they get away, but some game are easier to catch than others like squirrels for example. One time i was nearly straving and came back to my camp before it got dark and discovered one of my small deadfall traps had my dinner. There are aspects of the game i havent delved into yet, such as owning a dog which can help out with hunting. The game is turn based, but you can still get into trouble with burning your food if you go off and do a long consuming task or sleep, or you can have your food spoil if you do not eat it in a reasonable time or preserve it. There are NPC in the game whom you can trade with to get better quality gear which makes doing tasks much faster eg. chopping down trees with an iron axe instead of a stone axe. 21612213.review:
Hands down one of the best roguelikes I've ever played. Played the free version on and off in the past before buying it on Steam to show my modest support and appreciation for the Devs.

Being developed and consistently updated for over 20 years, Unreal World is set in a world resembling ancient Finland in the Iron Age. The gameplay has a ton of freedom and depth, and the setting is rich in its historical atmosphere and lore. 

There are many ways to play, you could be a farmer, hunter, a gatherer, a fisherman, a adventurer or trader as you find your path in this harsh, gritty world. There are no set rules, you decide where to go and what to do. Despite the simple graphics the gameplay is very realistic. It takes creativity and experience to accomplish some of the harder tasks like hunting. You really feel like you're part of the world as you make your way through the four seasons every year.

The game has its roots as a ASCII-based roguelike. If you've never played one of those before it might seem daunting to learn the controls, since for these games there're a lot of commands, akin to playing a flight simulator on the keyboard. It honestly isn't too hard to learn, and the in-game help browser and beginner game course is actually very helpful. If you don't mind learning the controls or if you're already a roguelike enthusiast like me, I highly recommend giving it a try.

21550984.review:
#Note: The game has been free for a long time, and is still free, over at the official website unrealworld.fi .

UnReal World is a procedurally generated top down rogue-like survival game set in a low-fantasy yet realistic version of iron age Finland, and because of this, the game is HARD, especially for new players. if you don't survive more than a week, remember that "losing is fun".

Luckily, for new players, the developers (A two-man group) have added two tutorials in order to help new players (one simpler, more focused on survival, one on more advanced mechanics).

As a rogue-like, the game has a skill system for rating your abilities in everything from timbercraft and construction to fishing and swimming. The base of these stats are dependent on your characters chosen tribe and their physical scores, randomly generated as you create your character. Your skills are then improved as you practice using them.

The game was first released in 1992, and it shows, in some ways. The UI can definitely be improved in some areas, among other things, but the devs are constantly improving the game and it is possible these issues are fixed later on. As an example of the overall attention to detail from the developer, The latest update (the first version released on Steam) added improved winter mechanics, making snow and ice thicker and thinner as winter comes and goes and adding the possibility of breaking the ice, adding another highly plausible way of dying during winter. Something else that has been in the game for some time is one of (if not THE most) advanced animal AI that isn't just randomly walking around, like other games.

In summary, it's a highly competent survival game, and the Steam version is currently just a way to pay the devs for the amazing amount of work they have done. If you feel like playing the game, go to their website and try the free non-Steam version first before buying it here.

21539291.review:
[h1] Unreal World: Vimba's Review [/h1] 

 I don't make many reviews here on steam, but this game deserves one so much. I've also played the game a lot longer before it came to steam and still do.

Edit: My low hours is from offline play from the non-steam executable. I don't know why I don't use steam. I guess I'm just used to the other way around. I bought it on steam because I wanted to support the devs. :) 

There is so much to say about Unreal World, but first I want to start off by saying that this is not a game that everyone will enjoy. Go check out the game on their website for free: http://www.unrealworld.fi/ 
 You have to put in some effort to learn the controls (which don't take long, depending on how custom you are with roguelikes and basic keyboard layout) You also need to be able to use your imagination (which is our greatest gift for video games) to immerse yourself in your own world. Once you feel comfortable with that, you are set.

[list]
[*]Unreal World sets the player close to the iron age of human history located in Finland. You can see from the start as soon as you launch the game that the traditional and folklore of the finnish culture is in place by listening to the music. The Kantele is being used which is part of the Finnish culture and it immediately tries to immerse the player in its rich world. 

[*]You choose a culture and then roll some stats. The world is then randomly generated and you get to choose a beginning "story" or setup to how you will play the first moments of the game. Each scenario has some sort of interesting background to help you be ready and immersed in the world. They are all interesting and some provide tools to help you get started.

[*]If you survive your initial scenario (depending if you chose a violent one) you are then free to do what you wish. Ultimately Unreal World is a simulator of sorts to show the player how our world is a dangerous one without the need of zombies and Rust like 24/7 violence. Like the Finnish Proverb says "The world will surely teach one; if nothing else, than to walk slowly." It's very true! 

[/list]

I won't go into details of what you can do because basically there are SO many things you can do and everything necessary is there to survive. If you were someone that read this because you thought you wouldn't be able to learn this or hate it for the graphics; well good for you b/c there are mods, in-game tutorials, encylopedia, and online guides.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
+ Very Immersive
+ A game that allows players to use their imagination
+ Awesome Developers (Thanks Sami and Erkka)
+ In Depth Combat System
+ In Depth Injury System from cuts/bruises, to diseases and so much more
+ Accurate Historical Items and Folklore
+ Easily Moddable
+ High Replayability

[h1] Cons [/h1]
-Roguelike Graphics: This is a con for some players used to modern graphics (Latest Update Improved them and mods help)
-Slight learning curve with keys (but is easily fluid once you get used to it)
-Could use more sounds IMO but overall very well done
-Pictures are somewhat corny but overall they do well (personal taste and easily moddable and mods help)

Overall, this is the TRUE survival game. I have over 400 hours of Rust and have played just about every survival game out there, but Unreal World just keeps pulling me back in for its in depth system of how we humans are adapted to survive in the impossible. This game allows me to use my imagination and do what I cannot do in my daily life.

[h1] Final Score: 95/100 [/h1]
Thank you so much for reading!

21524816.review:
I'm just going to start this review by letting potential buyers know that I've put several hundred hours into the free version of this game. I'm twenty-four years old so this game has been "In-Dev" my entire existence and it shows through in some good and bad ways*. When I saw UnReal World on Steam my jaw dropped, I loaded $25 onto my wallet, and bought it immediately. No regrets.

I'm going to do a light Pros & Cons to sum the why of it up.

Pros: 

+ Deep game mechanics.
+ Actually a survival game. (Unlike Rust/The Forest/ and others that make the claim)
+ High Replayability.
+ Immersive Lore.
+ Progressive skills.
+ Massive crafting system.
+ Extensive Medical system.
+ Many mods made by the community and refined over time.
+ Easy to create your own mods. Google the resources you need and the system is easy to learn.

Cons:

-- Mixture of Traditional & Digitized sprites for graphics.
-- Complex context menus required for maneveuring through the game.
- Basic/dated sound effects.


Neutral (Because this could be a plus for some, a negative for others.)

* +/- Overall a dated old-school look and feel.

  +/- A slight lack of "end-game" content, but reaching the end-game takes plenty of time and new updates are planned to rectify this.  A few of the planned updates are: family management, village ceremonies, and more. This is all detailed on the development page.

  +/- End game content  by 3rd party developers. I think that a game's merit shouldn't be based off the content created by the community, but while you're waiting on new updates things like the Shaman mod can give you your fix of additional content. It adds many "rituals" that feel lore-friendly and allow you to delve into spiritual magic and ultimately align yourself with light or darkness.

+/- It is lacking in music overall, but the new title screen music is promising.


Due to the time when the project was initially started the game has been stuck in the past as far as graphics, sound, and the general presentation goes.

The skin isn't beautiful, but the meat is sturdy and supple. [It must be a Kaumo.]
For those who aren't deterred by the time investment it takes to learn this game it is worthwhile and has more to come.

You can check out the developer's plans over on the website under the Development tab. 

http://www.unrealworld.fi/urw_development.html

Protips for those who intend to buy it/already have:

(I'll update this as I think of more.)

! Use the mouse wheel to zoom in/out. This is very useful for hunting.

! The help menu is your friend. Even for seasoned veterans.

! Dogs are man's best friends for a reason. They make hunting much easier.

! Humans used to use a method called "Persistence Hunting" to hunt down big game. The short of it is you use your incredible endurance to run an animal down and track it until it collapses from exhaustion then shower it with arrows or beat it to death in its sleep. How metal is that?

! Try to spawn close to the Driikiläiset people (Cyan on the map, toggle culture colors on) so that you can trade with their massive amounts of shops if you find a village. You'll do quite well for yourself by peddling your crafts to them for various supplies.

! Trap fences can be difficult to get the hang of, but making a house relatively near one can help guarantee your cellar stays stocked throughout the winter.

! When starving and tracking down an animal have ranged weaponry. 
You miss 100% of the shots you don't take -Lebron James on hunting, maybe.

!!! Don't give up. Every death is a chance to learn or try something different although it is frustrating to lose your progress. If you really don't want to lose out on it (and this is often frowned upon, but your own choice) then you pull up task manager (Control + Alt + Delete) and end the URW.exe process before going through the menu that deletes your character/progress. Everything that happened up to your death will be the same when you reload the game. You lose out on the experience, but it is your purchase and decision.


EDIT:  Actually, since I was born in 1992 and the game was released then it has been in-dev all my life. Wow.

21501010.review:
I cannot recommend this game enough!

Though I've only got a short logged playtime on Steam, I've been playin this game for about three years now from its pre-Steam releases.

To put into perspective the ungodly amount of effort that has gone into this game, I'll piont out that it has been in development since 1992. I *think* that makes it the game with the longest development time - at least more so than either Dwarf Frotress or the Duke Nukem. 24 years of work, as of the time of this review in 2016.

So what can you do in this game? Good question. You might recall how Todd Howard likes to say of Bethesda's releases that you can 'climb any mountain' or 'do anything' - well, you couldn't. In UrW you can come a whole lot closer to doing anything, though!

Every aspect of life (bar taking a shit and fucking someone, which is probably for the best) is covered. A massive amount of attention to detail has been made, and there are absolutely shedloads of historically accurate items, foods and activites you can access. What's more, the game (despite being a roguelike and keyboard-based, which may initially pout a lot of people off) is very accessible due to its fantastic in-game wiki.

What I've always loved in particular is that you set your own goals, something that no other RPG I've ever seen has done so well:

* Want to hunt a bear? Sure, get tracking! But first you need to make sure you're well prepared. Should you take the spear, the bow or both? Is it worth buying a hunting dog to help you out? Maybe you'll need a companion from a local village to cover your back? How much food will you need for the journey? There are so many things to consider.

* Exploration is crazy in this game! I mean, the gameworld is literally Finland. The very size. It's enormous.

* Perhaps it's time to settle down; building a settlement in UrW is incredibly rewarding, but by no means easy work! I've never found anything as satisfying in a game as having completed a gleaming wooden longhall, complete with mead benches and a roaring hearth. It took me several in-game months to achieve and arrived just in time for winter. Winter is brutal in this game!

* If you somehow feel your options aren't already wide enough, the game is incredibly easy to mod! Making and adding mods are both simple processes and widely expand the gameplay; what's more, since modding for the most aprt relies on adding .txt and .png files, there's practically a 0% chance that you could damage your game with mods (unlike certain other franchises), so go crazy!

A final note is that the UrW forums having been running for years and in that time the developers Sami and Erkka have been amazing; they have listened to every player suggestion, answered every question they could and are highly aware of what can make the game better. There never has been, and never will be, a shitty update. It's been getting better for 24 continuous years, and can only improve in the future! Make sure to visit the game's website and check the future development goals.

Thanks for reading this far!

21486715.review:
I have been playing URW since 2001, version 2.60.  After 15 years it's awesome to finally see it come to the mainstream public attention, and I have nothing but praise for the game.

At its core, it's your basic roguelike game: perma-death, turn-based, keyboard-heavy and with 2d pixel tiles instead of fancy graphics. Actually, it started out way back (it's in development since 1992) as a fairly standard fantasy game, but then slowly transformed into a realistic life simulator in the setting of iron age Finland.

You will have to survive by crafting needed stuff, hunting/gathering/fishing/putting out traps and get food, wood and pelts to make items and/or to trade for things you can't craft like axes or pots, and get better armor and weapons to fight off wild beasts and nasty humans (they come in the form of either bloodthirsty Njerpez warriors that will only settle for your death, or simple robbers that will try to get your stuff either by talking or by bludgeoning you over the head). Also of course you'll get tired and need to sleep, eat, and drink.

The game has a day-night cycle, full-on weather and seasons system: in summer the temperatures are bearable even without being covered head to toe in furs, berries and plants to eat are readily available, there's plenty of game to hunt and life is generally easier (you will get mauled by a bear nonetheless, don't worry)

At the other end of the spectrum, winter is harsh: days are short and nights are long, it gets freezing cold and you WILL die from hypothermia so you have to build shelter, possibly an elaborate log cabin complete with fireplace, table and bed, make enough firewood to keep warm and get a decent source of food or a good plan for having enough in those long, boring months. Ice will cover the rivers and lakes so to fish you'll have to poke holes in it, and if you're not careful you can walk on thin ice that will break and drop you into freezing water. Also snow accumulates on the ground and unless you have skis, you won't be able to walk very long without getting incredibly tired so you better have everything you need not too far away. On the upside it also allows you to spot tracks much easier. Too bad there are few animals around in winter...

I could speak about the game all day but this would become too long, so I'll just say one last thing, and it's the thing that impressed me most:

This game is a labor of love. Over the many years I've been playing this, a LOT of things have changed, and always for the better. Just since last year or so, there's a totally new trading / reputation system with villages, most exploits have been squashed and replaced with sensible mechanics, you can command your pet dog and it's even more of a killing machine, new animal AI especially for predators that will actively hunt their prey (have sheeps in a pen? be careful of wolves!), addition of more birds and seals you can club, and the list goes on and on. It's a truly well supported game that is worth at least double what they're asking, so if you're interested in this kind of game and don't mind that it's keyboard-heavy and has 2d graphics, it is a MUST BUY.

21481707.review:
I've been thinking about this game lately. I'm huge fan of this game and it's been a long while since i've played it. I have played countless hours of this game. I was reallu surprised to see this on steam! I had to buy it. 

The steam market is over saturated with multiple poor "survival" games that take all inspiration from minecraft. But this game has uniques spin on it. It's been in development from the year 1996. This has been a passion project of one man. Since this has come to steam I had to buy it. 

This game is based on fictional ironage Finland. It's the only game that embrases finnish-culture bigtime. 

This is REAL roguelike game! Turns, tiles, permadeath, perma everything, super hard and super depressing. It can be daunting to use this games interface. It's mostly keyboard driven. It' will take sme time, but in a while you'll get to enjoy a deep game.

What is this game all about: survival in wilderness. REAL survival. You are only human in huge, vast wilderness. You'll get cold, hungry, thirsty and injured. You'll die and you'll mourn your ancestors. 
The world in this game is HUGE and there is lot to do. The wilderness does not care about you. It's mostly empty and youäll rarely even see wildlife. It's realistic in that way. Some times you'' get to meet other people in settlement or just wandering around wilderness just like you. Some of them are even hostile. But the main enemy here is the wilderness it'äs self and inevitable winter. Winter is to be dreaded.
Mostly it revolves around getting food. Yes the real survival is all about food. You may be farmer, wich is hard, because winter is always coming. You can hunt for you food, but animals are superhard to catch and some of them are just ready to kill you instead. You can fish wich can be good, but you may drown while setting nets or starve when waters are frozen. Sometimes you'll need to rely on cannibalism, but this is surely way to get killed. 
There is crafting in this game. You'll get to build your house or some basic equipment. House is essential, because it's shelters you from winter. You can craft some weapons, but only crude ones. Best ones you need to buy usually with valuables like fur, food or equipment. YOU are not Tony Stark who builts everything out of box of scrap.

There are tons of features to be mentioned. 

Play this, and be free.

21480714.review:
A brief story of Bone of the Owl-tribe:

I'm stumbling through the woods when I find an abandoned camp. The camp has pretty much everything I need except water so I take off looking for water. I must have been wandering snowblind and dehydrated because when I snap out of my stupor I'm standing in the middle of a frozen lake. I learn this just in time to fall through the ice. 

I am finally able to get out of the water and back on to the ice, so I then start crawling for the shore. I get to the shore and I realize "hey, I can make a hole in the ice and drink the water". As I am raising my axe to punch the hole, some tribesman I do not know walks up and politely informs me that I will donate all my stuff to him. I tell him to go to hell and as bad as I just wanted a drink of that cool water, I turn the axe on the interloper who then whistles for his friend (up to this point I though that his use of the words "us" and "we" was just an eccentricity...like the royal "We"). 

With an axe in one hand and a knife in the other I am getting the better of this upstart worm of a thief, but I can see his friend has come out of the treeline with a huge - what I can only describe as a "pole". I guess it was supposed to be a staff but no normal man would wield this giant piece of wood as a staff. I get back to the business at hand and I have finally killed the thief who started this whole affair.  When I look up again the other thief has closed the distance and brains me with this monstrous tree that he has carried with him. I black out.

The next thing I know, I am waking up in an unfamiliar part of the forest (sans axe and knife) and twice as thirsty as before. I crawl for what seems like days when I see a village...

21480515.review:
Unreal World is an incredible example of what Roguelikes can be. In solid, continuous development since 1992, URW has no end in sight, with Enormous Elk (developers Sami and Erkka) continuing their work in bringing Iron Age Totally-Not-Finland to life.

URW is the epitome of survival games, yet predates the current craze by literally decades. It's realistic, it's tough, it's unforgiving, and extremely rewarding to play. There is a lot of depth and complexity to explore, and you can live your (probably short) life as a fisherman, hunter, trader, hermit, cannibal, raider... whatever strikes your fancy.

Roguelike mechanics, charming tileset graphics, and harsh survival interweaved with a touch of mysticism and the spirit of nature (which is simulated in great detail, from plants to animals to weather and seasons). Playing URW is simultaneously zen, and at times stressful (when you fall from a tree and break all your limbs and freeze to death, or almost anything to do with bears). 

Highly recommended, and sold for a pittance. If you have doubts, check out the developers' website for the free version. If you find yourself enjoying the game, pitch in on Steam to support it years to come. This is a true labour of love, and with all things going well, will see years and years of improvements ahead.
